name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 27 April 2017.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before I give the floor to the fellow Members who have asked for it as a point of order, I would like to remind you that today we are celebrating International Family Day.This anniversary, established in 1993 by the General Assembly of the United Nations, is intended as an opportunity to promote greater awareness of the social, economic and demographic issues concerning the family.The family is the basic nucleus of our social organization, it is entrusted, together with the school, the fundamental role of training our young people and the transmission of the values on which our common life is based.This Parliament has always been at the side of the family, in particular we have always strongly supported the importance of ensuring a greater balance between family and work.On this day, I want to emphasize that we will continue to commit ourselves with conviction on this path.*****

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: – Mr President, I would like to make a point of order under Rule 11 on an event that took place on 27 April in Brussels outside the plenary. It was a demonstration by one of our Swedish colleagues, Ms Marita Ulvskog, who showed her solidarity with a Palestinian terrorist, Marwan Barghouti. This is a man who has been convicted of three terrorist attacks in which five people were murdered, including a mother of two children, and also of attempted murder, membership of a terrorist organisation and conspiring to commit a crime. He was acquitted of 33 other murders with which he had been charged through lack of evidence. In this House we cannot accept shows of solidarity with convicted terrorists. I demand that you, Mr Tajani, as the President of the European Parliament, take your responsibility seriously and look into this matter.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I appeal to you and to your colleagues in the Chamber to denounce that the Council and seven countries of the European Union are in fact blocking aid to the areas affected by the earthquake in central Italy.This is a proposal that would allow one hundred percent co-financing of the reconstruction of the areas affected by the earthquake.I remind all my colleagues that, seven months after the disaster, most of the citizens still live in tents and do not even have the appearance of a normal life.These are the moments when we have to show that the European Union really wants to change and thus show the solidarity of the European Union.Hurry up, we need to rebuild immediately!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I want to be very clear on this and other topics. I do not intend to stifle the political debates within this Parliament, if sanctions are asked for every intervention on which we disagree, unless they are declarations that violate the principles of the European Union, we risk turning Parliament into a kind of censorship. I absolutely do not intend to stifle the debate. You can agree or disagree, but if for every intervention during which a state is censored, a state is attacked or people are criticized as long as there are no extremes of violence, it is only political attacks , I do not think it is right to intervene with sanctions, because this discourse applies to one side and the other, on any subject. I intervened when vulgar phrases were said towards other colleagues or unacceptable phrases because they violated the values ​​of the European Union, but otherwise I think it is not right to intervene with sanctions. I take full responsibility for this, it being my responsibility to impose sanctions.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by Julia Pitera, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the 2015 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests - Fight against fraud [2016/2097 (INI)] (A8-0159/2017).

name: Julia PITERA
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! Fraud, together with any form of illegal activity that harms the budget of the European Union, must be combated effectively. It is possible only with the use of the right tools, and the selection of appropriate tools is made possible by knowledge of the facts. The European Union budget is intended to improve conditions in all areas of life. Any damage to the budget poses a serious threat to this goal. According to the Commission's 2015 report on the protection of the Union's financial interests, the amount of irregularities reported as fraudulent amounts to nearly EUR 640 million per year. Unfortunately, it can be assumed that the number is in fact even higher as not all cases are detectable and reported. The EU must defend taxpayers' money as effectively as possible, but there are various obstacles to this task. One is insufficient cooperation at various levels, another is the fact that not all countries implement the rules on time. There is also no uniform system for collecting comparable data from Member States. The report that is being debated today highlights a number of issues. I would like to remind you only of the most important ones. These include the amount of revenue foregone due to the VAT Gap and intra-Community VAT fraud, and the fact that only two Member States collect and share statistics on revenue losses caused by cross-border VAT fraud. A worrying phenomenon is the increase in the number of reported irregularities in three agricultural funds for at least the next five years. The sharp increase in cases of irregularities relating to the common fisheries policy is noteworthy. There are also concerns about the increase in irregularities and frauds in spending on cohesion policy. Analyzes of this phenomenon by the Commission and the Member States in line with the ECA's recommendations, they could help to stop the worrying trend. Likewise, the reasons for the high level of fraudulent cases in R&D and business innovation should be explained. Among the problems identified, the most important one is the lack of uniform reporting rules applicable in all Member States. This failure distorts the real picture. Another serious problem is the lack of an information exchange system between competent authorities in order to avoid transnational fraud. They also require special supervision of derogations from the applicable procedures when using funds to help refugees. Undoubtedly, ex ante and ex post controls help to inhibit negative phenomena, thanks to which more and more irregularities are revealed. At the same time, it is worth emphasizing preventive actions: they are easier than recovering funds. The entry into force of the directive criminalizing counterfeiting and putting money into circulation is to be welcomed. When discussing issues related to the protection of the European Union's financial interests, it is impossible to ignore the role of whistleblowers and the need to protect them. Therefore, it should be noted that appropriate internal regulations have been introduced in the institutions of the European Union. Investigative journalism plays a similarly important role. The report also provides a comprehensive overview of the functioning of OLAF, including the results achieved, the duration of the investigations and the analyzes prepared. Thank you for your attention and I am looking forward to your contributions to the debate.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very grateful for this opportunity to participate in this debate on the Parliament’s yearly resolution on the protection of the European Union’s financial interests. The fight against fraud is of the utmost importance for the Commission, as it is for the Parliament. Protection of the European Union’s budget is all the more important at a time when the trust of citizens in the European project and in its capability to bring security and prosperity is at risk. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the members of the Committee on Budgetary Control, and in particular Ms Pitera, the rapporteur, for the excellent work done on this motion for a resolution. The result is a comprehensive and well-structured report which covers a broad range of issues. It is also thanks to the political pressure exercised by the European Parliament in its annual resolutions that several issues highlighted in the Commission reports have been addressed and progress has been made at European and at Member State level. Over the last five years together, we have significantly reinforced a framework for the protection of the Union’s financial interests. Let me recall just the most important measures that we have adopted. We have adopted several important acts modernising the legal framework for the protection of the financial interests of the European Union such as the revision of the OLAF regulation in 2013, the package on public procurement directives in 2014 and the four delegated and four implementing acts on irregularity reporting. The legal framework for the programming period 2014-2020 for the first time refers explicitly to the obligation for Member States to put in place proportionate and effective anti-fraud measures. On the revenue side, the revised regulation on mutual administrative assistance in the customs area entered into force, creating new databases to fight better customs fraud. The last and not the least of these legal achievements is the directive on the protection of the Union’s financial interests by means of criminal law, for which a political agreement was finally reached, also thanks to the persistence of the Parliament. But this is not all. There are also important ongoing legal initiatives. The negotiations of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) have moved forward very fast in the last month, and we now have 17 Member States willing to establish the EPPO in enhanced cooperation and a few more making preparations to join it. Like the Parliament, the Commission supports establishing a strong and efficient EPPO with as many Member States as possible and with the necessary means to effectively fight crimes affecting the Union budget. We are convinced that the EPPO has significant potential to improve the current situation as regards the low level of prosecutions for crimes affecting the Union’s financial interests. OLAF will continue to play a key role as regards non-fraudulent and fraudulent irregularities. It will complement and support the work of the EPPO. Beyond the protection of financial interests it will continue also investigations into serious facts by members of the institutions and staff, likely to lead to disciplinary or criminal proceedings. The Commission is determined to maintain a sufficiently strong OLAF which will operate across all Member States and will thereby play a crucial role to ensure that an adequate protection of the European Union’s budget is assured in the whole European Union. Over the last five years we have also made progress on concrete actions and measures. I will mention three examples for which the Parliament’s support, reiterated in the Pitera report, is once more important and particularly welcome. The first is the embedding of anti-fraud measures in national anti-fraud strategies. The second is to extend the use of IT tools by all Member States to strengthen the fight against fraud, and the third is the accomplishment of harmonised and qualitative reporting of the detected irregularities and frauds by the Member States. The Commission acknowledges that the reported data are still not fully comparable and takes note of the request of the Parliament to improve the situation. New guidelines are being prepared in cooperation with national experts to address the most important issues to reduce disparities and standardise the reporting process. The document is expected to be finalised this year. It is by analysing such data that we can ultimately understand whether the measures we have adopted really make a difference. However, there is still much to do. The Commission will keep on fulfilling its role of supporting and assisting Member States where needed and of facilitating the exchange of best practices and know-how. I would like to close my intervention, stressing once more the importance of the Parliament’s resolution. It is by acting together towards the same target that we have achieved all these improvements. But we are aware that we cannot rest on our laurels. We count on you to keep on stimulating, encouraging and also criticising when necessary – the Commission and the Member States – in their fulfilment of the Treaty obligation to protect the Union’s financial interests from irregularities and from fraud.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime I thank the Commissioner for his introduction and I thank Mr Pitera, rapporteur, for the excellent work he has done. The report on the protection of financial interests for the year 2015 unfortunately shows once again a significant increase in fraudulent irregularities and cases of corruption in various areas of interest of the European budget. In this scenario, the PIF directive and the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office are now fundamental tools to effectively combat crimes against the financial interests of the Union, but also, and consequently, to combat organized crime and terrorism which, by now we know, they are often financed also through such illegal activities. However, pending the entry into force of these instruments, action is needed to strengthen the coordination capacity between the national supervisory structures and to ensure closer cooperation by Member States with OLAF, given that, to date, one third of the reports of this Office have not yet been followed up by the national authorities. And coordination appears to be the sector on which we still need to work. Indeed, we cannot fail to note the absence of an administrative mutual assistance instrument aimed at improving the exchange of information within the structural funds. In fact, I had already, in the context of my parliamentary activity, reported this need in 2015 but, after two years, this proposal has not yet been followed up, which today appears more necessary than ever, also considering what has been said and underlined by OLAF. Another fundamental profile is that relating to the possibility of arranging for the coordination of joint investigative actions, under the aegis of OLAF, to be carried out simultaneously in the member countries concerned. The European Union has already developed a very important experience in the field of criminal judicial cooperation and I am convinced that exporting this experience also in the area of ​​administrative investigations can represent an added value. All this, however, must go hand in hand with the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office which, as the Commissioner pointed out, will be born through the enhanced cooperation procedure and therefore coordinated action is needed between administrative checks and criminal investigations. Last but certainly not least, in the fight against cross-border fraud is the role that whistleblowers can play. The delicacy of their role and the importance of their task necessarily require a European and national regulatory framework that clearly defines rights and obligations, and on this I hope that the Commission can proceed as soon as possible to the preparation of a legislative proposal to that effect. . Certainly a lot has been done and there is still a lot to do, but as Parliament we are fully committed to protecting the financial interests of the Union.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! The report raises many questions. Today we are looking at how well the control and reporting systems for irregularities and fraud are working, and looking at the report makes one rub your eyes. The number of reports of irregularities has doubled - with 81% more damage in four years - but the number of cases of fraud has decreased by 26% in the same period. So if you want to believe that, I don't. That means, the question is: How exactly do we look? And how exactly do we want to know? Commissioner, you yourself mentioned the fact that the Commission feels that this is strange and that it is concerned for the first time because of the comparatively low number of reports. How will the Member States' conflict of interest be overcome? When Member States report fraud, they have to repay the money they received. There is a strong inhibition to report fraud, and the available figures do not allow me to come to any other conclusion than the attitude “We just close our eyes and do not report it.” It cannot be that different Interpretations of reporting practice lead to different assessments of what is fraud and what is irregularity. So here the Commission should actually be much more advanced, and here you should also deal much more intensely with the question of the harmonization of reporting systems! I am struck by the fact that we take note of numbers every year and no one is interested in what actually becomes of the numbers. This year it will be different: we will ensure a follow-up. We also ask how efficient OLAF is. If you look closely at the numbers, then the cases with recommendations have not changed for many years. As long as the OLAF Supervisory Committee doesn't really has access to closed cases in order to deal with the question of the efficiency of OLAF, as long as it does not work.So I think these are major building sites and it would be good if the Commission did something about that too.Something else worries me: 75% of all fraud is detected through administrative controls.This is not a success story, as 25% is not discovered by administrative controls, but by chance.That is a hair-raising number.Here, too, there is an urgent need for action.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. president. I wish to thank Mrs Pitera for her report, which again seems to us to be a very interesting report. Although we have to say that what we are waiting for, and we believe that part of the solution that we are demanding, will come from the hand of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. That we would like since, once sixteen Member States have proposed enhanced cooperation, to see if an agreement is reached as soon as possible on the framework, the legal framework, and especially the means and capacities of a European Public Prosecutor's Office proper, which can finally fight really, with all guarantees but at the same time with all means, against fraud as is. It should also be said that we are in a situation in which we are again facing a multi-annual budgetary cycle, with all that are the cycles of funds - including the part of the crisis that has paralyzed a large part of that application. Hence, as Mrs Gräßle very well said, the times, the calendar in which the different Member States are asserting or announcing, denouncing and reporting their irregularities - be they fraudulent or not fraudulent, that I believe that the distinction it is important to do it - it has been quite chaotic. And in that sense, I too believe that an effort must be made, Mrs Thyssen, on the part of the Commission, to ensure that the calendars of the Member States are truly harmonized and comparable. On the other hand, we also have a situation in which there is a contradictory application, I would even say a bit schizoid, of the name and shame principle, because if the figures are very high - as has happened, as has been said - then it turns out that there are to criticize the Member States because what they have denounced was very high; but if the figures are low, they are also reported, because they have not reported. In other words, at some point, Mrs. Thyssen, I think it would be very important that the institutions, we would agree on how it is denounced, on that harmonization and, above all, on who is doing it well or badly, and not do a kind of totum revolutum to end up announcing disasters that are not such, sinceAs you very well said, progress is being made and what we need is to demonstrate these advances in a reliable and clear way.And finally, I would like to ask you for something.Here we are talking, and it is true, of the irregularities of 80% of the budget, which is the shared budget;But we also lack evaluations of a part of the budget that is growing exponentially, as is the case of Horizon 2020 and even of the EFSI guarantees, and in whose new twists and turns we find situations of deep concern: for example, the casethat these days has returned to jump in Spain on the Castor project within the scope of the FEIE.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, the fight against fraud against the European Union budget must be intensified, because only in this way can smuggling and various other illegal activities be tackled effectively. According to the report, 75% of all fraud cases are related to goods such as tobacco, electrical machinery, footwear, textiles, iron and steel, all of which come mainly from China and the United States. United Arab Emirates and Ukraine. Also a serious issue is what is called counterfeiting, ie "monkey" products that again come from China, Hong Kong, the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, and India. We need to tackle this issue as well as the smuggling of tobacco, as at least € 10 billion a year is raised from this illegal activity, which finances other illegal activities. OLAF must also be very effective, especially in the way in which NGOs use European Union funds to support refugees. NGOs are currently having a party in the Aegean islands, Commissioner, and OLAF should intervene, because money is not going in favor of refugees either, and there are still problems, and of course in the Aegean people, who can no longer stand others. refugees and illegal immigrants.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the comprehensive report and the Commissioner on her statement. We are still struggling to overcome the effects of the recent financial and economic crisis and some of the consequences associated with the decrease in confidence of European citizens towards the institutions. This dramatically increases the role of the protection of the European Union’s financial interests as one of the most relevant ways to restore its attractiveness. In the relevant annual report 2015 there are several aspects that are of the utmost importance for the achievement of the main goal of the protection of the EU’s financial interests. Firstly, the total number of irregularities detected both by the Commission and the Member States is increasing for a second consecutive year. While there could be different reasons for this fact – including better control, an increased level of spending or simply a rise in fraudulent activities – we need better preventive work by the institutions.  Secondly, the anti-fraud measures undertaken by the EU institutions in Member States should target both the revenue and expenditure sides of the budget. The final goal is to secure better revenue permitting the implementation of stronger policies, while keeping the irregularities in expenditure under control increases the credibility of the institutions.  Thirdly, from a managerial point of view, we need a full implementation of a budget focused on results strategy. In the process of designing and implementing management and control systems, cost effectiveness should be pursued. This means that the control strategies should target predominantly the areas with a high risk and error rate. Thus the control would support the achievement of results without imposing an excessive administrative burden on beneficiaries. Finally, I would like to underline again the importance of the efforts made by both the Commission and Member States in the protection of the EU’s financial interests. All of the fraudulent cases raise public attention and damage the reputation of the Union. The proper functioning of the preventive and corrective mechanisms and adequate action taken by the Commission services to protect the EU budget are indispensable in achieving major results in the fight against fraud.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Pitera. We had excellent cooperation during the whole discussion period, and I think that finally the outcome of this discussion is really an excellent report, which I recommend to the Parliament to support. It is important that in the Committee on Budgetary Control there was a broad consensus on the report. It is a good sign that the different political groups coming with different political backgrounds could agree on the most important issues regarding the protection of the financial interest of the European Union. There are several points in the report, and I would like to point out only four important issues from my perspective. First, as was already mentioned, is the question of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO). I agree that it is an important progress and development that finally we could agree and that as an enhanced cooperation the EPPO could start its work within two or three years. On the other hand, we have to keep in mind that this enhanced cooperation at the moment consists of 17 Member States, and that some of those Member States who are the most critical, from the point of the view of the spending of the EU funds, are not part of the EPPO, and this raises the issue: how can we put pressure on those Member States where we can experience a high level of corruption, if they are not part of the EPPO? From this perspective I believe that the strengthening of OLAF competences is something we have to do to have the rights and the competences to better control the spending of EU funds in the Member States. The second issue is the anti-corruption report of the European Commission. This was published three years ago, and it was promised that every two years we will see an anti-corruption report. Now the Commission shelved this anti-corruption report: this is exactly the wrong message to send to the Member States and those who are in the corruption business if the European Commission is not doing its best to mop up corruption in the European Union. The third issue is the whistle-blower protection. It was already mentioned that whistle-blowers can contribute a lot to protect the financial interests of the European Union. We have to help them and protect them on the European level, not only on the Member State level. Finally, if the investigative journalism is in line and in parallel with whistle-blowers, investigative journalists can do a lot. Thank you for the rapporteur to support this idea. We need to support and protect investigative journalism in the EU.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too thank my colleagues in the CONT committee for the work we have done this year with a lot of dedication. From our point of view, it is very important to increase transparency in the area of ​​public procurement and subcontracting, where numerous frauds often infiltrate, and above all that there is collaboration between Member States to avoid cross-border fraud. We see how easy it is to circumvent the control system when using particular crossings within the Union, so it is essential to cooperate on this issue. Another fundamental issue is that linked to European law in general on organized crime. To date, since there is only one avant-garde country, namely Italy, in the law against organized crime, it is easy for international criminal formations to settle in European states where the law is not at the forefront and therefore take over the ports of the Northern Europe, cigarette trafficking and then, let's see, migrants, where the situation is very difficult and not very transparent. These are our main points.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! The present report on the protection of the EU's financial interests also raises very important questions and challenges in the area of ​​tax fraud. As the rapporteur has already said, we can really only tackle tax fraud if the problem is clearly identified and then solved efficiently becomes. The thrust must certainly be to ensure that the funds are used properly and thus to restore the citizens' trust in this area. A major problem in the area of ​​tax fraud is certainly the issue of VAT. The rapporteur pointed out in detail in the report: VAT, at 12.27%, is the most important source of income for the Member States of the European Union and also the Member States. And here we see that in the area of ​​fraud prevention a VAT gap of 160 billion euros is shown every year. Carousel fraud alone accounts for 50 billion of this - more than a third - and thus organized crime. VAT gap means that the outage is caused by both fraud and VAT avoidance strategies. We are also familiar with tax avoidance strategies from other areas. Here, the failure due to tax avoidance strategies and aggressive tax planning in the budget of the Union and in the budgets of the Member States can be estimated at 60 billion euros a year. There are only two Member States in the European Union, the United Kingdom and Belgium, that have statistics on revenue shortfalls due to cross-border VAT fraud. There was also a special report by the Court of Auditors, which found that the EU system was not effective enough and that there was a lack of comparable data and indicators on intra-Community VAT fraud is impaired. However, the Member States have a large number of interesting instruments at their disposal for combating VAT fraud. In particular, there are the following problems: a lack of cross-checking between customs and tax data, problems with the exchange of data between the tax authorities of the Member States and insufficient cooperation between the administrative judiciary and law enforcement authorities. And - what has already been mentioned today: the number of reports of irregularities is increasing - the number rose from 2014 to 2015 and more than a third - the number of reports relating to fraudulent activities has, however, decreased, namely by 11% in the comparison period. I would agree with the previous speakers: You have to follow up on this, that cannot be done with the right things. Another thing to think about: 52% of these fraudulent cases are in the agricultural sector, so special attention is required here. So what we need is more transparency and better cooperation in order to give national budgets and the EU the funds they need back.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the fight against fraud is a key condition for the protection of the European Union's financial interests and is the responsibility of all Member States. One of the areas in which fraud must be combated is the global trafficking and illicit trade in tobacco products, which smuggles huge quantities of cigarettes and is so responsible for the loss of many millions of revenue by states. as well as to create risks to the lives of consumers. Like almost all governments in the European Union, Greece is showing an inexplicable and possibly suspicious delay in implementing measures to combat smuggling. Specifically, while since June 2016, it has passed a law for the supply of machines that will track tobacco products from the place of production to the place of consumption, it has not yet conducted the relevant tender. In addition, it has taxed the price of cigarettes and forced tobacco retailers to use electronic payment machines, resulting in banks receiving 1% commission, losing revenue and, at the same time, pushing people to try to find the products. these in the illicit trade and thus endanger his health. Immediate protection measures against smuggling must be taken and implemented immediately worldwide.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Today, the EU is facing a huge degree of mistrust on the part of European citizens. Today, more than ever, it should show that it is a matter of transparency, that it is a matter of reaching out to the electorate, that of European citizens and restoring credibility not only to the European institutions, but above all to the Member States that make up the EU. In many Member States, the EU has lost credibility thanks to its leaders. Commissioner, we applauded at the beginning, we applauded our determination to change something about these things, but unfortunately, as Mrs Pitera's report shows, you, like the European Commission, have not changed much in recent months or in recent years. It's something we have to focus on. The annual report reflects what is wrong with the EU, and our role as European politicians is to restore confidence in the EU. Protecting Europe's financial interests should be one of the EU's key priorities. We must prevent Europeans from seeing the benefits of the EU as an opportunity for fraud and corruption. Unfortunately, I have to say that even some high-ranking officials in the Member States themselves - and the Czech Republic in particular - are causing this. At the same time, corruption and fraud undermine basic democratic principles across the EU and cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of euros a year. In this situation, Commissioner, I am sorry for the approach of the European Commission, and I firmly believe that, after hearing our arguments, you will try to change it.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! Both the report under discussion and the debate here in plenary suggest to some of the citizens who are watching us that there are also cursed villains in the European Union and that there are governments and authorities in the Member States who are trying to recruit them well or badly. fight and sooner or later they will win with some solution. I am missing in the trial the special category in which a government of a Member State, through the imprisonment of the authorities under the governments of the Member States, systematically builds a system of money-using and taxing practices that are essentially designed to serve that government's criminal acts. This is the case, for example, in Hungary, where a body of legislation currently ensures that, in addition to the immediate family and friends of the Prime Minister, Viktor Orbán, virtually no one can access the benefits of various development projects financed by the European Cohesion Fund. Obviously, these governments - because I think there are more - they are, of course, also opposed to the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, given that by climbing up the legal-philosophical problems of other Member States, he from this special form of cooperation. I call on the Commission to pay attention to the context in which, unfortunately, the governments of the Member States are imprisoning public authorities and thus knowingly harming the financial interests of the European Union by committing crimes.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: - Mister President! There are many terrifying facts and figures in this report. But these should not just make us shout: We need more controls, we need stricter controls. We should also reflect for once: How can this even come about? And a very good way to prevent mistakes and also to prevent fraud is of course to think twice: What is this EU responsible for? Is she really responsible for everything that makes sense? Do all the rules make sense at all? Rules that you don't need are not broken. Therefore we should think again very strictly: Can we not demand more subsidiarity? Then many rules are unnecessary. We in the ECR Group also see no point in introducing a European public prosecutor. I believe that this will not lead to more transparency, nor will it lead to more proceedings being opened, but rather we will see that a European public prosecutor will have major problems of demarcation from the national public prosecutor's offices.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteur for the work she has done and I want to focus my contributions to this debate on three issues, Commissioner. The first is the need that Parliament has already expressed to establish a European anti-corruption code that allows: creating a transparent system of indicators on the extent of corruption in the Member States; publish the progress made to eradicate it; and present a comparative annual report on the state of this scourge at the European level. Far from tackling this task, the report claims that the Commission has stopped publishing comparative data in this regard. And it has done so not only without notifying this House, but also ignoring this very specific agreement of the European Parliament that appears in paragraph 148 of the Report on the situation of fundamental rights in the Union approved on September 8, 2015. The second it is the need to focus the benefits of simplification and reduction of administrative burdens on users. We know of cases in which, after the conclusion of a certain project, such as the European Employment Portal, the project coordinator now sees how amounts unduly paid to one of the partners of the consortium are claimed that, for reasons beyond the project, has gone bankrupt. The Commission cannot resolve your difficulties in interacting with the partner by harming a user and, in this case, the coordinator. Finally, it is essential to improve the data exchange procedures between Member States and to standardize the criteria for monitoring possible infringements and the communication thereof. The differences between the penetration of corruption in the different States and the irregularities they report are more than enough reason to be sure that there is, in this particular matter, a huge opportunity for improvement.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, this report identifies eye-watering levels of fraudulent activity costing the Member States of the European Union EUR 637 million in 2015. When you add irregularities that are not fraudulent, the total amount of money involved goes to over EUR 3 billion. That, of course, is just the known fraud and irregularities because as the rapporteur correctly points out, by definition, there must be more that is not detected. And that is also before even asking the fundamental question as to whether taxpayers got value for money from the cash that was spent.  But this report in a lot of ways beautifully illustrates the European project as a whole, because whenever you have more Europe in one area it will result in problems implementing across 28 countries and the European Union will inevitably have to propose more harmonisation as the answer. For example, you get proposed responses like a European public prosecutor’s office, because the system will fail to function without it, and responses include imposing rules across all 28 Member States.  This is the very essence of the acquis communautaire. Once power moves from a nation state to the European Union in one area, it inexorably follows that powers must continue to flow in that same direction. That is how the European Union is set up. Really, there can only be two honest positions here. Either you support a European super state, with all that entails, and the loss of sovereignty and identity that comes with it. That view is logically internally consistent, and however much I disagree with it, I respect those who honestly hold that view. The other position is to recognise that the alternative is to leave the European Union and to get off the train before it reaches destination super state. That is what we in the United Kingdom are doing. But I just think if only the European Union had remained as a trading organisation rather than a political monolith, I am sure we would not be in this position today.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - We are in a time when citizens' trust in the European institutions is declining, so we have a great responsibility ahead of us on how to restore trust. The transparent use of European money and the effective fight against fraud are important aspects of confidence in our work. In 2014, almost € 160 billion in revenue was lost due to the VAT collection gap, and € 50 billion due to intra-community VAT fraud. This is a huge loss that could be spent on creating economic growth and new jobs. Instead of seizing the many opportunities for swift action in the fight against fraud, we are still witnessing unreliable data reported by Member States as a result of insufficiently effective cooperation with the European Commission. There are also a number of gaps in cooperation between Member States, which should exchange information and best practices with each other. At European Union level, we need a strong and independent public prosecutor's office, which we must give sufficient powers to be able to protect the European Union's financial interests quickly and effectively. If we do not give the prosecution enough powers and ensure its independence, thus ensuring a high level of legitimacy, then this will be a lost opportunity to effectively combat fraud at transnational level. Only the coordinated action of the European institutions, the Member States and other relevant services will lead to a more effective protection of the European Union's financial interests.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the end, in any analysis, we must start from the statistical data. The number of financial irregularities has increased alarmingly: 36% in 2015 compared to 2014. It is an argument for an in-depth analysis, but also concrete measures. I support the report and hope that, once we adopt it, cooperation and cooperation between the Commission and the Member States will be improved, at the same time as between the competent institutions in each state. The analysis shows that the major source of revenue for Member States is VAT. Unfortunately, there is an increased vulnerability to tax fraud in cross-border transactions, Commissioner, and I think we need to focus on where the greatest vulnerability exists. Here there must be close and loyal cooperation between states to eliminate carousel fraud. Customs controls are very important in this chain of fraud detection, but it is clear that they are not enough. I also believe that control procedures need to be improved for products that are mainly used and smuggled because 75% of the total products are: alcohol, tobacco, textiles, electric cars; then there we have to focus on the controls, obviously also on counterfeiting. I welcome the ex ante and ex post community controls in order to detect irregularities that could prevent fraud in the future, but they need to be strengthened and streamlined and I support the rapporteur's position and I also call on the Commission to examine the possibility of Member States risks. Commissioner, I think that OLAF is doing its job, but we must also look at efficiency, it is not enough to have a statistical number of controls, but the effect of these controls is important and I come here with a concrete proposal: I think we should increased sanctions, sanctions must be tightened because any person who makes a mistake must be corrected if he does not want it through sanctions and in the end every euro counts and this euro does not necessarily belong to the citizen, not necessarily from the European Union.Everything goes to the citizen.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, an effective fight against fraud requires two types of attitudes: profound changes and reforms in the judicial systems of the Member States, especially those countries that have come out of long dictatorships, in order to adapt these judicial systems to modernity of crime, adapt these judicial systems to the demands of democracy. It also requires the courage to carry out in-depth reforms in justice at the level of the European Union. It is necessary to create a catalog of crimes exclusive to the Union and also to create courts with exclusive jurisdiction to try these crimes. The fight against economic and financial crime cannot be done through the twenty-seven Member States, through the judicial systems of the twenty-seven Member States. But the fight against this type of crime, economic and financial crime, is also done with political measures. Fraud is not disconnected from corruption and it is necessary to develop a political fight against corruption in the European Union, which discredits the Union, discredits democracy and injures citizenship itself with death. Finally, Mr President, Commissioner, taxpayers' money needs to be better spent. European Union political leaders need to spend taxpayers' money better.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! My dear group of visitors! We are talking today about fraud in the EU budget. It is about 22,000 irregularities, or three billion euros. The irregularities have increased by around 6,000 cases - more than a third. The Commission says: The number of irregularities has increased because the EU budget has also increased. And now the Commission and also the Parliament and some member states - including Germany - want to introduce a European public prosecutor to fight fraud. A prosecutor for a state that doesn't exist and that we don't want. My solution is a little simpler and better: less redistribution, less irregularities, less fraud. That is why we should cut the EU budget to what can only reasonably be regulated by the EU: e. B. mutual help in natural disasters, but no permanent redistribution and no subsidy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the protection of financial interests should be one of the fundamental elements of European Union policy in order to increase the confidence of citizens by ensuring that their money is used correctly and efficiently. On the other hand, I note that, despite the positive 11 per cent reduction in irregularities reported as fraudulent compared to 2014, in 2015 the corresponding amounts even increased by 18 per cent. The European Union and the Member States share responsibility for protecting the Union's financial interests, and national authorities manage around 80% of European spending. It is quite clear that the system of cooperation between the Commission and the Member States in the area of ​​fraud detection has significant flaws. OLAF's work must be facilitated and conditions must be established which guarantee the admissibility of the evidence provided, encouraging Member State authorities to conduct joint investigations. I too am in favor of setting up an autonomous and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, which has the necessary legal instruments and is able to work effectively with other existing European bodies and with the authority of the Member States.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate shows once more how pivotal the need for an adequate protection of the Union’s financial interests is. It also indicates that continuous improvements and enhancements are necessary to bring the fight against fraud and irregularities in line with the expectations of the European citizens. Please rest assured that the Commission is fully committed to continue to strengthen the protection of the European Union’s financial interests and to reinforce our efforts in this area. To ensure the European budget is delivering its optimal impact and value for money, the Commission and the Member States have the duty to make every effort to prevent public money from being defrauded. On your question or your statement that the total number of irregularities detected by the Commission and the Member States is rising again and what the reason is for this, I can only tell you that there is no straight answer to this question. Identifying the main reasons behind increases and decreases in the number of irregularities is always, as you know, a complex exercise. Several factors may contribute to this. In relation to 2015, increased spending, changes in control strategies and delayed reporting have played a role. I kindly refer you to certain paragraphs in the PIF report about this. On fraudulent irregularities, there we see that the number of fraudulent irregularities has been decreasing. I want to tell you here that interpreting the true meaning of the fluctuations in the number of this kind of irregularities reported and in their related financial value is always difficult and could easily be misleading. As observers we tend to associate the positive judgment to decreases and the negative one to increases of detected fraudulent activities. However, we should never forget that we are looking at the Member States’ capacity to prevent and detect fraud. It is the detection efficiency of Member States that counts. Of course, as many of you said money lost due to fraud is money we could use better, we could invest it in useful projects. But we also should know that reporting of irregularities does not always mean that the budget lost the amounts. Member States and the Commission often recover the amounts. Let us not forget that. And then, of course, we recognise that there is a conflict of interests. But let me tell you that we also addressed this conflict of interest among other things in the public procurement directive of 2014, where the definition of conflict of interest is introduced, and I can also tell you that the Commission prepared guidelines with Member State experts on conflict of interests. One Member asked me why the Commission decided to discontinue the anti-corruption report. Well, an effective fight against corruption within the European Union remains essential, delivered through the right vehicle. Fighting corruption has become a key element of the European Semester process. I want to underline that the Commission will take up anti-corruption matters in the context of its main economic policy dialogue between the Member States and the European institutions. This is in line with the general approach of this Commission to streamline processes and focus on key issues in the relevant fora. There was also a question on whistle-blowers and about the state of play on initiatives of the Commission on the protection of whistle-blowers. There I can tell you that the Commission is assessing the feasibility and the scope for European action to strengthen the protection of whistle-blowers. DG JUST is carrying out an impact assessment, has launched a public consultation in March and is about to launch a targeted consultation. The Commission should decide in July of this year what action to propose before the end of the year, before December. Despite my efforts I have probably not addressed completely certain specific or certain technical issues in my introduction or in my reply to your questions, but I can tell you that Commissioner Oettinger will meet the rapporteur, Ms Pitera, at the beginning of June in order to continue the discussion on how to improve further the protection of the European Union’s financial interests. Thank you for your attention and I can tell you that the Commission counts on the European Parliament’s continuous support.

name: Julia PITERA
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! I would like to thank the Commissioner and the colleagues who took part in this debate very much. I must say that with all the complexity of the issue and due to the fact that it is a subject of great concern to politicians, I am full of hope, because regardless of the political differences that divide us, this concern for the state of the budget, for the most effective elimination of all negative phenomena is a concern common, and this always gives hope for effective combating everything that is harmful to the proper functioning of public life. I agree with the order of priority that my colleagues have put forward here - reporting rules, the European Public Prosecutor's Office issue, control, OLAF are indeed the most important aspects of this report. As I said, I trust that our cooperation will lead to the fact that the phenomenon will be minimized and as little money will be lost as possible, because the level of trust in the European Union, European institutions, and European politicians also depends on it. Finally, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs once again very much, who have indeed made the work on this report extremely fruitful, very interesting and very harmonious.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The fight against fraud against the Union must be fought decisively. Indeed, the annual report indicates an increase of 36%, which makes decisive action absolutely necessary. Major weaknesses regarding prevention and control concern the VAT sector: losses due to the VAT gap and intra-community VAT fraud are responsible for the loss of revenue of EUR 159.5 billion and EUR 50 billion respectively in 2014. An analysis of the feasibility of homogenization of the same is therefore urgent, as is the intervention in other sectors particularly affected by the phenomenon: agriculture and fisheries. Three types of intervention are key to tackling the problem: increased scrutiny, increased exchange of information between Member States and, last but by no means least, the establishment of a common framework for effective whistleblower protection.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control draws up its annual report on the fight against fraud in parallel with the clearance of accounts procedure. The report reviews the efforts made to protect the Community's financial interests. It calls on the Member States to cooperate more closely in detecting fraud and to strengthen controls, which are essential for more effective action. One of the biggest problems remains the smuggling of high-tax products, which causes a serious loss of revenue for EU and Member State budgets. Customs and border controls at the Union's external borders need to be strengthened in order to combat smuggling and fraud more effectively. The report also shows that statistics based on the number of cases of fraud and irregularities reported by Member States can often be distortive, and it is therefore important to make a clear distinction between errors and fraud. He emphasized the role of the European Anti-Fraud Office in protecting the European Union's financial interests, but criticized the fact that the average duration of OLAF's investigations continued to increase. I also supported the report in committee and in plenary.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mrs Thyssen for being here.  The European Qualifications Framework (EQF) is a European-wide qualifications framework, which joins the qualifications of different EU Member States together. In a way it is a translation of different national qualifications which makes qualifications in different EU countries easier to understand. As such, the EQF is of key importance for well—functioning European integration and mobility.  According to the Commission, the upcoming review of the EQF will make it even easier to compare qualifications across countries. It will help learners, workers and employers to better understand what a job applicant knows and is capable of doing. The revised EQF is also supposed to facilitate the comparison and understanding of the qualifications of third country nationals.  These are important and admirable goals. Nonetheless, on the revision of the EQF, Parliament has adopted an oral question. The question – or really the questions – reads as follows:  Qualifications differ across the European Union and that makes it difficult to assess the knowledge and capabilities of workers and learners. In 2008, Parliament and the Council adopted a recommendation on the establishment of a European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning with the aim of improving the transparency, comparability and transferability of qualifications in Europe. The EQF’s objectives have not yet been fully achieved. Therefore, as part of its New Skills Agenda, the Commission is proposing to revise the system through a new Council recommendation. Question 1: how will the proposed recommendation facilitate equal opportunities in the knowledge—based society and a better permeability between the education and training system? How will it help to match the supply and demand of skills in the labour market?  Question 2: why would the revised EQF work better? Why did the Commission deem a revision necessary, despite the current framework being only partially implemented and Member States’ calls to focus on this? Question 3: how is the framework contributing to the swift validation of informal and non—informal learning? How is the new relationship between ECTS and ECVET expected to work? Question 4: how will the Commission support a consistent implementation of the EQF across Member States, its use and involvement by all the relevant stakeholders, as well as its better visibility? Question 5: by using the EQF as a meta—framework, how will the Commission ensure that the specific features of national training and education systems can be recognised and understood in the other Member States?  Question 6: the growing migration flows to and from the EU highlight the need for a better understanding of qualifications awarded outside the EU and of their recognition in order to help migrants and refugees integrate into EU labour markets. How does the Commission intend to support the development and application of mechanisms to enable the comparison and recognition of third countries’ qualifications? In the resolution by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs that will be voted by Parliament on Wednesday, it is also highlighted that relevant stakeholders – such as public employment services, social partners, education and training providers and civil society – should be further involved and closely cooperate in the creation, implementation, promotion and monitoring of the EQF, at EU level and also at national level, in order to ensure its broader support. We have also highlighted the importance of Member State commitment and involvement. So far only the Netherlands and Sweden have specific procedures put in place within their plans for the inclusion of non-formal qualifications. No Member State has specific procedures for informal learning within their national qualifications frames. This is an unnecessary barrier to the labour market. We should always respect national competences and guaranteeing that the distinctive traits of the education systems of the Member States are safeguarded but, at the same time, many Member States are still in the early stages of implementing their national qualification systems. This is too slow if qualifications are to be comparable across Europe. We have to see improvement here if a fully functional EQF is to be achieved. We also need to make sure that employers know how to use the system so that it can truly be the tool that we all want it to be. Improving the EQF is key to achieving our common goals, namely to see that people are not jobless and do not end up in a desperate situation with high unemployment rates. Commissioner, we look forward to hearing your answers to all these questions.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you Ms Ulvskog, let me start by welcoming your engagement and contribution to our work on the new Skills Agenda for Europe. I know that you are currently working on a report on the Skills Agenda and I look forward to reading this. Your question today on the European Qualifications Framework (EQF) comes at the right moment, as in one week’s time the Council will adopt the new EQF recommendation. Let me now address the issues raised in your question. Firstly, I want to stress that the EQF is a success story. In the almost 10 years since it was established it has helped to make qualifications more transparent and therefore more comparable across Europe. Twenty-four of our Member States have national qualification frameworks in place and have completed the referencing process of EQF. Others will follow this year. Citizens across Europe are already benefiting from the EQF level on their diplomas and certificates. This makes it easier for their qualifications to be understood in other Member States. This is why phase 2 of the EQF represents an evolution, and not a revolution. Compared to the 2008 text the eight qualification levels remain unchanged. The key principle remains: this is a transparency tool, not a recognition tool. EQF levels will feature on individuals’ diplomas and certificates and Member States, participating countries and social partners, indeed also social partners, will continue to meet at European level to agree the correct referencing of each qualification framework. But the world of qualifications does not stay still. People are increasingly learning in different settings and are rightly demanding that this learning and experience is better recognised. This will happen even more in the future. Qualifications and national qualification frameworks are adapting. This is why the new EQF recommendation proposes a continuous updating of the referencing process in order to ensure that this keeps pace and the referencing remains. As highlighted in your question and in your motion for a resolution on the EQF, equal opportunities and permeability should be strengthened. This is valid both within systems, for example to make progress from vocational to higher education easier, as well as between different systems and countries. I am sure Parliament will welcome therefore that our proposed revision puts a greater emphasis on credit systems to support flexible learning pathways, including by setting our principles for credit systems in a dedicated annex, that is Annex 5 as you know. And of course linked to this, a call for the proper recognition and validation of non-formal and informal learning in line with the dedicated Council recommendation of 2012. Member States are invited by the EQF to incorporate this validation in their national qualification frameworks. Indeed for the EQF what counts are the outcomes of learning, and not the duration or the institution where the learning took place. Ensuring the consistency of EQF implementation is the task of the EQF advisory group. This group, created in 2009, has proven its value in building trust between Member States, and its work will continue. We will continue our work together with the advisory group to better communicate about the EQF and to improve its outreach to citizens and employers. We will also look more closely at the reality on the ground through studies and peer-learning activities. In addition, CEDEFOP will support the EQF process updating, the European Inventory on National Qualifications Framework, and all this should also help to make it more visible. You know that the EQF serves as a translation grid, a translation grid between different national education and training systems. It helps to better understand and compare qualifications that are part of these systems. The EQF therefore fully respects and protects each national education and training system. The goal is transparency and understanding. The goal is not harmonisation. Regarding a better understanding of third-country qualifications, the proposal includes a specific recommendation on exploring such comparisons. We should not have illusions, though. The reference to the EQF requires mature national qualification systems. Pilots to date have been done by New Zealand, Australia and Hong Kong, but this is not done in isolation. Migrants and refugees need our help now. Other actions of the new Skills Agenda for Europe focus on practical actions, practical action for a better understanding of the skills of third-country nationals. Next month I will launch a skills profile tool for this very purpose. It will be done on 20 June and this will coincide, as you know, with World Refugee Day. The new EQF also brings more clarity on international qualifications such as sectoral or industry qualifications. This will be achieved by expert and peer support to Member States for their levelling. The EQF has been a successful tool to improve the transparency of qualifications across Europe. It has stimulated Member States to introduce national qualification frameworks and it is a tool which individuals and employers are beginning use: people are referring to EQF levels in their CVs and I hope soon too in job adverts. The new EQF will build upon what we have achieved. It looks to the future to keep pace with changes in qualifications and continues to be at the forefront of skills transparency. Together with the nine other actions of the Skills Agenda for Europe we aim for a joined-up approach which promotes better skills in Europe.
