name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, today it is appropriate to talk about the qualifications and the revision that the Council, in the coming days, is going to approve of the European Qualifications Framework, within the work of the Skills Agenda that it has established during the last year, two years , the European Commission. For us this question is very relevant, for several reasons. Learning and the recognition of learning, formal and informal, throughout life are relevant, first, because of the profound changes that are taking place in the labor market, with increasingly vulnerable workers, with more temporary jobs and with a very worrying unemployment in some countries of the European Union; secondly, because the transformations within the labor market force us to make these changes, especially digitization; and, thirdly, because we have new groups at risk, such as people who have come to seek refuge, reception, in Europe, because this path is the path they can travel to enter the labor market. It is opportune to talk about this, it is opportune that we work on it, but there are several issues on the table. One: if we are going to be able to get the Member States to comply with the review, because it is true that with the European Qualifications Framework so far there are several States that have taken steps forward, but not all, and not all equally. Two: if we are going to be able to guarantee accessibility to all groups, also to risk groups, safely, free of charge and with public provision of this training. Three: if we are going to be able to listen to Parliament, because so far there has not been this work of listening to Parliament on this matter. And four: yes, at the same time, we are also going to be aware that not everything is going to be politics about supply, about learning, about workers, but also politics about demand; and that there are serious, serious problems macroeconomic factors that also generate unemployment.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. - Madam President, the opportunity to acquire new knowledge, knowledge or skills is no longer limited to a traditional school in an individual's place of residence. Internet, distance learning, study travel or volunteer work. Today, these are all ways in which individuals, whether young or lifelong, can improve their skills. However, the diversity of ways to acquire these skills automatically brings with it the need to somehow understand, evaluate and recognize them, so as to improve the individual's choice of employment and at the same time clearly name to the employer what skills the job seeker has. The European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning is a tool for Member States to better understand and recognize skills acquired in other countries' education systems, or in non-formal and informal learning. Although the Recommendation on the European Qualifications Framework was adopted in 2008, its objectives of transparency, comparability and portability of qualifications have not yet been fully achieved, and it is therefore necessary to further develop and streamline this instrument in order to make it easier for employers, workers and and learners an understanding of national and international qualifications as well as qualifications from third countries. In this regard, Member States must step up their efforts to recognize formal qualifications and diplomas more quickly and effectively, as well as the additions to certificates and references of the relevant EQF level, and should make the results of the referral publicly available at national and European Union level. In this context, it should be recalled that it is the duty and exclusive competence of the Member States to pay attention to the quality of teaching content and the organization of education systems, and that the European Qualifications Framework does not interfere in any way with this responsibility.

name: Renate WEBER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we are living in a world that changes every day and facing constant technological challenges that demand the continuous development of knowledge, skills and competence. Both the private and the public sector require skills that were almost unconceivable 30 years ago, and in adapting to these changes we should no longer follow old-school ways when it comes to education. Yet our education and training systems lag behind this new dynamic, limiting the recognition of non-formal and informal learning, including the skills gained during volunteering activities. This is damaging, not only in relation to a short-term economic outcome, but also to the main aim of education: generating adaptable and independent individuals able to face the challenges ahead with open minds and confidence. Greater flexibility in skills recognition is beneficial for European citizens, and can also lead to better economic and social integration for migrants and refugees, thus responding to another challenge of the EU. At the same time, through structured dialogues with the EU neighbourhood countries, especially the ones that have an association agreement with the EU, we should aim at referencing their national qualification frameworks to the European Training Foundation. In this way, if sooner or later these countries become EU members, their citizens will be ready to cope with the demands of the European markets and labour force from day one. Moreover, EU support through development aid should be directed to third countries in order to offer assistance in developing national qualifications frameworks. The revision of the European Qualifications Framework should result in an innovative meta-framework that responds to all these existing challenges but also think ahead, anticipate potential problems and offers ‘out of the box’ solutions.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, we cautiously appreciate the Commission's initiative to promote the European Qualifications Framework to improve the comparison of training and knowledge of European workers, especially migrants from another Member State or third countries. This should be a fundamental tool to facilitate the recognition of the skills of workers who are frequently discriminated against in the labor market, as well as to contribute to the national design of active policies. And it is within this framework that a new Recommendation should be promoted, and not force a standardization of training that goes to the detriment of national specificities, or that evaluates them only considering their economic potential. In this regard, we ask the Commission to focus on strengthening its collaboration with the Member States, with the social partners and with the public employment services.

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that, however much I may share the work and the project we are talking about, we are analyzing the problem while ignoring two fundamental points. The first is that we are leveling education systems by adapting them to processes of change towards globalization, which exactly distort what was the true essence of the education system as conceived not only within the European Union, but also in individual Member States. Education should be a moment of personal and cultural growth of young people and today, instead, we are moving exactly to the opposite side, we create an education system that serves the labor market as we want it or as we plan it, made of globalization , made up simply of changes to which not everyone can adapt. From another perspective, it is as if we wanted, or were in some way, treating a terminally ill patient with aspirin because, no matter how hard we can do to be able to stem the qualification problem within the European Union, we know very well what is the underlying problem, the fact that today unemployment is a real and dramatic problem and if we do not start to solve the problems from the base, that is where it is mainly necessary to act, whatever other measure we find, seek or imagine will not be effective nor efficient. If we do not create jobs, if we do not make expansionary maneuvers to support employment and if we do not try to solve the very serious problem of unemployment at all levels, we could talk about all this but it will make no sense, and it is no coincidence that we find ourselves to talk about mobility. I will give you an example by giving you some data: last year 110 000 young Italians left my country because there are no prospects, and believe me, dear colleagues, that the young people who left had qualifications, they had titles, they had skills, but they found a country that doesn't know how to value them.This is the reality, we have to start solving the problems at the root because we build and are building a house starting from the roof, but we never put a solid foundation.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Mrs Thyssen, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union wishes to set up a European qualifications framework for lifelong learning. The objective seems quite laudable since it is a question of ensuring a better match between the skills available and those which are lacking in the labor market. Moreover, the idea of ​​taking into account the three levels of knowledge seems relevant to us. Knowledge, skills and competences can be acquired formally and informally. Unfortunately, the motion for a resolution devotes an entire paragraph - paragraph 7 - to the inclusion of migrants and we strongly oppose this policy, given the 25 million unemployed in Europe, including 4 million young people. On the other hand, we fear that these equivalences will level down and thus devalue our training and our diplomas. Moreover, this question of equivalences raises the broader question of mobility. This better equivalence of skills is in fact used as a pretext for developing worker mobility, thus promoting social dumping, a source of more precariousness. Finally, the European Union has tried in the past to standardize training without any real success and this new system does not seem doomed to be more successful. For all these reasons, Madam President, Madam Thyssen, dear colleagues, we will vote against this text and table amendments so that this framework does not become mandatory. Member States should be able to remain free to recognize formal or informal qualifications according to their own criteria and needs. You have the wrong target: new regulations must be established to preserve fair competition and not further promote unfair competition between East and West, or even new competition between migrants and the European unemployed.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). - Madam President, the so-called European Qualifications Framework for Lifelong Learning has been working for all these ten years to strengthen the EU mechanisms in all Member States, so that a large part of the population has an abundance of single-skilled workers, others in a lifelong mobility apprenticeship to change up to ten occupations in their lives. This constant wandering between unemployment and flexible work with the piece, is the reality that shapes the capital, the European Union and their governments in all Member States with the aim of maximizing capitalist profitability. The European Union is updating this strategy to include refugees and migrants with the same goal: cheap, flexible and subjugated labor. In this line, the SYRIZA-ANEL government, at the same time as bringing the fourth memorandum-slaughterhouse of labor rights, receives the congratulations of the European Union, because it promotes, among other things, with the apprenticeship label, hot money subsidies to employers which will now reap even unemployment benefits. The only answer is to organize the workers 'popular struggle in order to put obstacles in the capitalist workers' galley, so that the people can stand tall. And on this occasion we call on the workers in Greece to take part in a massive, decisive participation in the nationwide strike on May 17 against the anti-labor ban of the government, the European Union and capital.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the European Qualifications Framework is the main tool for simplification of mobility of employees and greater comparability of the qualifications system. Qualifications differ across the European Union, which makes it difficult for employers to assess skills. The European Qualifications Framework should facilitate opportunities in a knowledge-based society and ensure a better permeability between education and training systems in order to improve the match between the education programmes and the needs of the labour market. The Commission proposes to revise the system, as the Commissioner has just stated here. I would like to emphasise that the Commission should focus more on the implementation of the current framework, because the current framework has not been fully introduced yet by Member States. So we have new proposals on the table. When implementing them, the Commission should create an effective system with involvement by all relevant stakeholders. It is also very important that the Commission support a mechanism to enable comparison and recognition of third countries’ qualifications and the swift validation of informal and non-formal learning. We have asked the Commission relevant questions in our oral question, and we also tabled relevant recommendations in our motion for a resolution. I am looking forward to a fruitful debate and cooperation on new legislation.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that the employability of workers cannot fail to be a priority objective on the European agenda. Employability and competitiveness are two unavoidable steps for a Europe that grows and develops. The enhancement of skills, knowledge and skills unlocks the extraordinary potential of our human capital. The tools for assessing the skills already acquired or, even more so, necessary in a changing economy that explores new spaces and new opportunities are a fundamental step to allow an effective crossing between supply and demand for work. In short, the labor market today places the need, in a context of flexibility, to constantly and permanently update the contents of training courses, therefore shared criteria of comparability of education and training processes make these courses even more transparent, improving the employability of workers and promoting their mobility. There is another great opportunity, in the time when the migratory flows of citizens in various capacities set the goal of their real integration, the correlation between national and regional qualifications frameworks of third countries and the EQF seems to be a absolutely not negligible need. Therefore, it seems necessary to promote the transfer of qualifications between the various education and training systems from one State to another, in order to support the demand of the business system and thus promote employment. Again, and I conclude, the best possible answer, this, to the new technological and demographic challenges to finally write the new political agenda of work, rights and equal opportunities.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Madam President! The European Qualifications Framework is a long-term ambitious instrument which promotes the professional mobility of citizens between countries and facilitates their lifelong learning. The framework places the emphasis above all on learning outcomes in three categories: knowledge, skills and competence. Thus, the new priorities of the Strategic Framework for European cooperation in education and training by 2020 enable learners and workers to better present their skills, no matter where they have acquired them. But unfortunately the devil is in the details. How to apply comparable mechanisms and recognition of qualifications obtained, for example, in third countries? How is the new system of mutual dependencies between ECTS, i.e. the European credit transfer system, and ECV, i.e. the European credit accumulation and transfer system in vocational education and training supposed to function? How to unequivocally define the concept of competence? And so on. All this with a very important assumption: there must be no violation of the competences of the Member States in the field of education and employment policy.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, our topic is the 'European Qualifications Framework for Lifelong Learning': seven words that cover the shortfall in real employment policies. We present them as a panacea for unemployment, because we forgot full employment. We make them the flag of our policies. But is this how the work problem in Europe is solved? Millions of young, but also experienced workers, with very good scientific and professional qualifications, remain unemployed for years and their qualifications are useless. I suggest that we change priorities: first and foremost, generous spending and employment, because otherwise a hasty change in the European qualifications framework can serve as a mechanism for increasing the number of unemployed.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for this important tool, which says something about the Europe we want. In the area of ​​education, the role of the European Union is to build bridges between the different actors and the different policies, whether social, economic, youth or education, to show that paths are possible. Member States have agreed to establish certifications that refer to the European framework. We need to organize the portability of qualifications in Europe so that they respond to the realities and changes in society. The European Qualifications Framework is a crucial instrument to improve the employability and mobility of learners. There are as many relevant journeys as there are individuals. It is essential that the courses offered are flexible and the training accessible in order to improve one's skills and progress towards a qualification, towards a certification, that is to say recognition of the skills acquired. The issue of mobility is important, in particular for young people and cross-border regions, who are well aware of the importance of this recognition of skills and diplomas. The revision of the certification framework common to the whole of the Union must make the link between the certification systems of the different States. This work must be able to rely on the revitalized social dialogue in order to establish a better match between qualifications and the job market and to integrate the challenges of mobility and lifelong training.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Madam President, lifelong learning is currently proving essential for gaining a foothold in the labor market, introducing new technologies, automation, robotics and new information technologies. Since the financial and economic crisis, we have approved and implemented many support programs for education, retraining and job creation. But it turns out that the unemployment rate in the Member States is still very high, despite the fact that we have many vacancies in each country, because there are not enough applicants with the necessary qualifications or skills. The link between education, training and employment was a guiding principle in the creation of the European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning. We all know that education and training systems fall exclusively within the competence of the Member States, so the European Qualifications Framework should allow for targeted exchanges and cooperation between Member States so that the recognition of qualifications and skills is not an obstacle to gaining a foothold in the labor market. free movement of persons. As the objectives of the original European Qualifications Framework have not been met, the question for the Commission is appropriate and I fully agree with it why the revised framework should work better, as the current one has only been partially implemented. Member States that carry out the tasks of the European Qualifications Framework also call for the implementation of the original one. I also agree with the other questions that have been asked, and I expect well-founded answers from the Commission.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the European Union has created a space for the free movement of workers. But in order for this right to be realized, a basic condition is the mutual recognition of qualifications, the mutual recognition of professional qualifications, both formal training and non-formal training and education, and I think this is in favor of the workers themselves, because employers in the various Member States obviously do not want this mutual recognition to exist. Because, in the absence of this recognition, they hire all employees with the lowest wages. So it is in favor of the employees themselves to make this recognition and proceed with the process. I would say, of course, that the report places great emphasis on recognizing the qualifications of refugees and migrants. This proves that the goal is to create a reserve army, which will essentially reduce the wages of the workers themselves in the European Union, a European Union filled with armies of the unemployed.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's new proposals for the European Qualifications Framework are following suit and leading to a stalemate. Stimulating digital skills in sectoral work, more information in specific areas, revision of the Europass framework. These in themselves bring neither growth nor reduction in unemployment. We need public and long-term investments, integrated strategic planning, policies that cover both the training of employees and the creation of new decent jobs. The current costs incurred by the state for internships in companies are not a strategy against unemployment. It is a clear support for increasing the profits of companies. The responsibility for employment cannot be unilaterally borne by the employees. Approaches such as lifelong learning, professional development, immigration, so-called "employee mobility" are not solutions. On the contrary, they are levers of labor rights.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Madam President! The EQF for lifelong learning is an important tool to promote the mobility of trainees and workers. In 2006, as EQF rapporteur, I was able to ensure that equality between vocational and academic education was enshrined. We wanted Copenhagen to have the same value as Bologna. The comparability of knowledge, skills and competencies should be decisively improved. It was possible to establish eight levels of education and thus to cover the entire spectrum of education. Unfortunately, the content has not yet been sufficiently implemented in the Member States. That is why we rightly ask the European Commission to what extent we can achieve a more specific definition of the EQF, to what extent there can be better cooperation in many cases between the providers of training and the national authorities. I think it is important to preserve the peculiarities of the national systems. This has shown in Germany: Our dual training is future-proof, and our master craftsman's certificate is by no means a hurdle to be overcome in the domestic market, but has been an example of competence and quality for decades. May we succeed in simplifying, standardizing and improving the instruments EQF but also ECVET in the intended reform. Let's reduce bureaucracy and increase flexibility! We employment politicians see this as providing European added value and inspiration.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, I fully support the revision of the European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning, because I believe that this will improve the transparency and comparability of qualifications obtained in the various Member States. In the age of rapidly evolving technologies and the ever-changing labor market, European citizens need a wide range of skills to help them develop professionally. Unfortunately, qualifications acquired abroad, as well as skills developed outside the formal education system, remain unrecognized and underestimated. European citizens suffer from this because it limits their opportunities for professional development, employment and promotion. For these reasons, I believe that the revision of the framework should result in greater visibility of skills acquired outside the classroom. To date, only the Netherlands and Sweden have introduced procedures for the recognition of informal qualifications. I call on the Member States to give more visibility to non-formal and informal learning, including volunteering, in national qualifications frameworks, because this will provide more opportunities for young people to reach their full potential.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank the Commission for taking the decision to revise the European Qualifications Framework. This framework has not been fully implemented to date, although it was published perhaps six years ago, and it is worth asking yourself why. After all, the European Qualifications Framework was created as a response to the urgent need to make it possible to compare diplomas and qualifications. If such an important and urgent goal is not met, then there must be a reason, and in my opinion the reason lies precisely in the tool. We have seen how difficult it was to translate the European framework into a more specific national framework, and in this resolution and in today's voices, we hear that they are simply insufficient, that there are new challenges, that there is the issue of recognizing qualifications acquired outside the formal education system. Today, for example, we have probably 40% of specialists in the IT sector, very high-class specialists who acquire their qualifications just outside the formal education system, so there is a need. There is also a need to understand what the diplomas and certificates mean of people who come from outside the European Union and come here to work, so yes, this change is very much needed. I think that these ideas of automatically indicating the level of the European Qualifications Framework they correspond to on diplomas and certificates issued in Europe would greatly contribute to making this framework more popular and more recognizable for the average citizen and employers. I still consider the postulates included in the New Skills Agenda to compare national qualifications frameworks very important. It is very necessary to compare these national frameworks, to analyze them and to exchange good practices.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the diversity of learning structures and educational pathways represents an opportunity for sustainable economic development as well as for personal development of learners and citizens. I know from personal experience that lifelong learning develops creative and critical thinking, helping us to gain in self-confidence, to become problem solvers, entrepreneurs and responsible citizens, and to acquire the intercultural social and transversal skills needed to achieve more inclusive, open and tolerant communities. We are often asked to equip learners with skills and competences for a world that does not yet exist. Therefore, properly including lifelong learning in our education policy is key, and promoting EU collaboration and harmonisation across Member States is important. In the context of demographic changes, flexible economies and uncertain job markets characterised by increasing digitisation, robotisation and automation of production, we must also embrace the concept of occupational literacy promoting active engagement in arts, citizenship and sport. Furthermore, we must include refugees, as they have much to offer and they arrive with skills and a desire to contribute.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - The idea of ​​a European Qualifications Framework seems to me to be a very good idea. Education, and in particular the link between education and the labor market, is a very important area, so I support all efforts to recognize non-formal learning and to recognize non-formal skills. If we have and want to complete the single market, we need, of course, greater unity in the recognition of inter-gender qualifications and skills. The free movement of people is one of the key freedoms, and although we may have a different feeling, labor mobility in the European Union is not fully exploited and this option is used by very few people, a very small percentage of citizens. In the event of changes to the single qualifications framework, labor mobility would be further encouraged, which would of course have positive long-term effects on the economy. People looking for a job abroad face a lot of problems, of course mainly with the recognition of their qualifications, but they are not the only ones who have problems. Of course, employers also have problems recognizing what skills these people bring with them. Therefore, it would take some kind of certification to be able to use uniform criteria and to know who offers what on the labor market. That would be good for everyone.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the free movement of persons is one of the rights most highly valued by our citizens and one of the pillars on which the internal market is based. Despite this, the lack of comparability, recognition and validation of qualifications between the different Member States is a major obstacle for many Europeans to find work outside their borders. Therefore, making education and training systems as diverse as Europeans easily comparable will be a very positive step towards our goal. I consider it important that the European Qualifications Framework be deepened and fully applied in accordance with other instruments such as Europass, Eures or Erasmus. As a result, the supply and demand for skills can be better matched to the labor market and companies will be able to more easily interpret the qualifications and competencies of candidates, which will promote the mobility of workers between countries and ultimately help to create jobs. Currently, Member States are in the process of adapting their national frameworks to the European one and many of them are still in an early stage. Therefore, I wonder why you are considering renewing this Framework, which has not yet been fully implemented and for which we have not yet been able to assess its impact.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Ms. President! Dear colleagues! With regard to the questions addressed to the Commission, I would like to point out how the technological and innovation environment will have an impact on the recognition of qualification levels. Let us not forget that, despite all its mistakes, the European Union is one of the most balanced regions in the world. Why is this important? According to the United Nations, the integration into the labor market of migrants from outside the EU, often without even basic qualifications, can take many years, even a decade - just to think about the lack of language skills. To give an example, a technician in a North African country was able to learn his profession on machines that were technology decades ago. The qualifications of this person cannot be practically recognized as equivalent to that of a European skilled worker. As technology evolves faster, these are increasingly real issues. We must not make this a political issue. That is why I particularly support the amendments that protect the high quality of qualifications. This is a fundamental interest. We need to strengthen the competitiveness of the European Union in the future.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to state in advance that every reasonable citizen, every entrepreneur in the European area must support the strengthening of employees' competencies, their professional growth, and, of course,, of course, the comparison of vocational and academic education. The problem here is that just a few years ago, the goals set have not yet been met. The problem also lies with the Member States, their insufficient implementation of the set objectives. It is this inadequacy that is a major problem in terms of meeting the rules on which the EU stands. If the Union is failing precisely in these basic rules, which are then to serve to fulfill those fundamental freedoms of the EU and the single internal market, then I think it is really failing. Above all, we should remove those administrative obstacles that have already been mentioned here in the recognition of, for example, those qualifications. It is the task of the EU to remove barriers, and I just hope that in the few years that this framework will be reviewed again, our followers will not have to say that the expectations and goals we have set ourselves have not been met. I firmly hope that this proposal will be further promoted at the level of the European institutions.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, although the European Qualifications Framework has been a significant driver of reforms in the setup of national frameworks, as the Commission is also aware,  not all the objectives of the 2008 recommendation were reached in terms of comparability and portability of qualifications. This is why, if we take European cross-border mobility of learners and workers and lifelong learning seriously, it is important that we make qualifications more transparent and understandable across different countries and different educational systems. One of the greatest challenges in referencing national systems in a common framework is posed by the changes over time in qualification systems. This makes it necessary to keep referencing activity constant and up to date, especially considering the increasing proliferation of international sectoral, industry-based training and certifications. I would especially welcome if the Commission could provide more details on this.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, I asked for the floor because I want to add some things to the debate. First of all, of course, I agree with at least one of the motives for this debate, which is the harmonization of degrees. That is right. But, ladies and gentlemen, one of the main issues we need to see is that Education is commercialized. One studies three by three plus three, nine years of study, maybe more, and in the end has no job. This is the most essential. And I remember a conversation that I do not know who said it, I do not remember now, and I think it's good to hear in plenary: I went, he says, very well with my education until I was sent to school. I close by saying that, that is, what we lack is an Education with a humanitarian background. In addition to finding work, which we do not find anyway, to produce creatures that humanize man and the European citizen.

name: Milan ZVER
text: - Mr President-in-Office, Commissioner Thyssen, I would like to congratulate you on tackling this important work, the amendment of the European Qualifications Framework. I remember in March 2008, when we finally adopted or confirmed the first document with this title, at that time, as the Prime Minister responsible for the Presidencies, I also signed this document and I consider it a great honor. Of course, almost a decade has passed and I am not the most satisfied with the implementation of this document in the Member States, but given what you mentioned earlier, this year practically all countries will implement all the key elements of this framework, it is still ... it is, however, a matter of success. I am especially glad that you will amend, update the basic document. Here, however, we must conclude that it is not a question of recognizing qualifications, but of transparency and comparison of these qualifications, if we did not have the opportunity to compare educational outcomes between different countries, of course European education systems would continue to go their separate ways. This document allows us a kind of harmonization and easier comparability of qualifications.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! The European Qualifications Framework for Lifelong Learning, which was established almost ten years ago, was an important step towards greater transparency in the recognition of qualifications, which was expected to contribute to facilitating labor mobility within the single market. The proposal for new Council recommendations in this respect shows, on the one hand, that the European Qualifications Framework is applied in all Member States, but on the other hand, it shows that the description of similar qualifications has not been converged, which makes their transfer and mutual recognition very difficult. I believe that Member States should strive to further harmonize national qualifications systems and frameworks to common European standards. It is also equally important to promote the application of this framework among education and training institutions and employment services to ensure its greater visibility. Only thanks to this, they will be able to become a universally applicable standard. I hope that the proposed new Council recommendations will prove helpful in this regard.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the House for today’s debate that shows the importance we all attach to the European Qualifications Framework (EQF). I will not go into the details of your questions one by one, but I would like to stress that the EQF is a tool to make skills and qualifications more transparent. It is not about automatic recognition or the harmonisation of national qualifications frameworks. Secondly, the EQF revision builds on the achievements of the recommendation of 2008, and it will make the EQF a more effective tool adapted to the reality of today and to the evolving nature of qualifications. And finally, the future success of the EQF is in the hands of Member States and stakeholders, who are in charge of implementation. The Commission’s role will be one of support. I count on your continued support for the EQF and for other initiatives within the European skills agenda. It is our joint responsibility to offer citizens the necessary tools to develop their skills and find the jobs that are right for them. This counts especially for the still more than 19 million unemployed people in our Union. Skills are of the utmost importance for them, so we are working on this, including by improving the EQF. This is only one of our actions to create more jobs, more growth and fairness in our Union.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday 17 May 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - 2008 A Recommendation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning was adopted in 2006 to increase the transparency, comparability and portability of qualifications in Europe. This recommendation called on Member States to link their qualifications systems and levels to the eight levels of the European Qualifications Framework and, by 2012, indicate the level of the European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning in newly issued certificates or diplomas. The objectives of the European Qualifications Framework have not yet been fully achieved and the European Commission is already proposing to review the system on the basis of a new Council Recommendation. It would therefore be important to know whether this new recommendation will help to ensure equal opportunities in the knowledge society and better link education and training systems, and whether it will help to match skills supply and demand in the labor market. These issues are important because the EU's education and training systems differ, and it is difficult to assess what a person who has acquired in another country knows, knows and is able to do. Insufficient understanding does not allow confidence in the quality and content of a qualification obtained in another Member State. Lack of confidence in such qualifications makes it more difficult for workers with these qualifications to develop professionally, find employment, reduce opportunities for promotion and further training, and create obstacles to the mobility of workers and learners in the EU. Thus, a proper understanding and assessment of existing skills and qualifications is essential to help them be acquired or updated, as this will help to better match skills supply and labor market needs.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The EQF - a common European reference framework that interconnects qualifications systems in different countries. This framework acts as a kind of translation tool, making it easier to read and understand the qualifications that can be obtained in different European countries and education and training systems. It has two main objectives: to support lifelong learning and to support mobility between citizens and countries. Experience to date has shown that Member States are not sufficiently committed and, despite their commitments, there is still a lack of transparency of qualifications and a low rate of recognition of foreign qualifications. To this end, the EQF needs to be continuously developed and adapted, supported and improved through regular monitoring, in particular as regards its user-friendliness, interoperability and transparency. I therefore support the real commitment of the Member States to the implementation and use of the program in order to make it a success. The effective functioning of the EQF will help sectors and individuals to make the most of the opportunities offered by the internationalization of qualifications; and will have an impact on education and training systems as well as on the labor market, industry, trade and citizens. The European Union must enable everyone, regardless of age or status, to make their skills and competences more visible, including those acquired through volunteering, and to recognize them in a clear and accessible way, especially in cross-border areas.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: signed up. - The European Qualifications Framework for Lifelong Learning is a crucial tool for improving the employability and mobility of European citizens. We live in a constantly changing world in which the demands of the labor market are growing, requiring a rapid and continuous adaptation of knowledge, skills and abilities. Unfortunately, education systems do not follow this dynamic, and the recognition of non-formal and informal learning outcomes is still very limited with a negative impact on employment and professional development opportunities for a significant part of the population, especially for vulnerable groups. I therefore believe that the revision of this qualifications framework must also take into account the increased visibility and importance of skills acquired outside the classroom, which will facilitate equal opportunities in a more open, tolerant and inclusive Europe.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Biljana Borzan, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the Resource Efficiency Initiative: reducing food waste, improving food safety (2016/2223 (INI)) (A8-0175/2017).

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, the European Union, as one of the most advanced and richest communities in the world, has a moral and political obligation to reduce the huge amounts of food thrown away every year. As long as there are soup kitchens and social supermarkets in our cities, one kilogram of discarded vegetables is too much. As long as our fellow citizens dig in the containers because they are hungry and one loaf of bread that is thrown away is too much. As long as children are starving in Yemen and Somalia and one bag of flour being thrown away is too much. 55 million Europeans cannot afford a quality meal at least every other day. About 88 million tons of food are thrown away annually. A situation in which 20 percent of the food produced is not eaten or thrown away is unsustainable and immoral. The aim of this report is to propose to the European Commission and the Member States policy and practical measures to reduce food waste along the entire production-sales-consumption chain. Maintaining food safety standards is our red line because public health is our priority. The report calls on the Member States to take the necessary measures to reduce the food waste target in the Union by 30% by 2025 and by 50% by 2030. To achieve this, we need official definitions of food waste and loss and a common methodology for measuring these appearance. Parliament considers that when proposing new laws that may affect food waste, the Commission should carry out an impact assessment so that we actually know whether a particular law will have a positive or negative effect. Education is key to reducing food waste. It is estimated that more than half of all food waste comes from households. The report calls on the Commission, Member States, local governments and other stakeholders to carry out educational campaigns to inform the public about the value of food and the prevention of food waste. An example is the misunderstanding of the difference between “use by” and “best use by”. Less than half citizens actually know that there is a difference and that food can still be consumed after the “best to use by” date has expired. We ask the Commission to review the appropriateness of the current labeling system and propose changes if necessary. In some Member States, VAT is still levied on food donations, which is in fact a direct consequence of European legislation. Some countries have circumvented these regulations, but we believe that the best solution would be for the Commission to propose an amendment to the VAT Directive that would explicitly grant tax exemptions for food donations. At the same time, some Member States encourage donations through tax breaks and other economic incentives for socially responsible companies. We believe that such and other examples of good practice should be promoted throughout the European Union. EU funds and programs such as the Most Needy Fund and the Agricultural Fund for Rural Development have the potential to increase donations and reduce losses in food production. We consider these opportunities to be underused and call on the Member States to become more involved in this matter. Citizens' awareness of this problem is at a very high level today and that is why we must not miss the opportunity to act. Honorable Commissioner of the European Commission, Honorable Representatives of the Member States, Parliament is asking you to reduce food waste in the European Union because closing your eyes to this problem is deeply immoral. Thank you.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am delighted to be here today to take part in this important discussion.  Food waste is an issue which is very close to my heart, not only because of my personal history, but also because food waste is unethical and immoral. Indeed, it is shameful to throw away food in a world where more than 800 million people go to bed hungry every day. Therefore we – institutions, industry and science, households, and also as individuals – can make simple gestures to make a real, tangible difference. I hope I am able to show, via my numerous interventions and participation in events throughout the European Union and beyond, that the Commission is fully committed to leading the European Union’s efforts to fight food losses and waste from farm to fork and to make solid progress towards achieving the United Nations sustainable development goal of halving food waste by 2030. Efforts to prevent food waste will not only increase resource efficiency, but will also reduce unnecessary pressure on the environment, reduce costs and really enable surplus food to be redistributed as a priority to those in need. Indeed, tackling food waste is one of the examples with a strong social aspect where successful businesses can benefit our people. By delivering better food, we deliver better health and quality of life. By creating commercially viable business models, we provide jobs. To be successful in all these tasks, we need focused coordination of all relevant policies at European Union and Member State level, which is rightly pointed out in Parliament’s report. I found the report very comprehensive and I welcomed the holistic view taken in the analysis and proposals put forward to prevent food waste and, more generally, to strengthen the resource efficiency of the food supply chain, including the management of water as a key strategic resource of the agri—food industry. I can assure honourable Members that I, together with my fellow Commissioner, will closely analyse your requests for action in the areas of environmental protection, agricultural policies, fisheries, finance, education and communication – to name just a few. I am also glad that the report follows the guiding principle of all Commission action on food waste, which is that food safety and the protection of both human and animal health remain our absolute priority and shall not be undermined or compromised in any way. With its circular economy package and related action plan, the Commission translates this general objective into a set of actions with clear commitments and deliverables.  The first commitment was already achieved when the Commission launched, in November 2016, a multi—stakeholder forum dedicated to food waste prevention, the European Union platform on food losses and food waste. The platform brings together both public and private interests, including Member States, stakeholders and international organisations, to spearhead European Union efforts to tackle food waste. At the first meeting of the platform, Members welcomed the establishment of this unique forum, integrating all players as a means of helping all actors to design ways of eliminating food waste from our food systems. The platform will soon meet again, giving stakeholders the opportunity to share experiences, business cases and successful models to allow their replication in all other Member States and business sectors and possibly bring these up to EU level. The platform is also a forum to help us deliver our next commitment, namely to elaborate a methodology to enable Member States and actors in the food value chain to quantify food waste in a consistent and comparable manner and to adopt, in 2017, EU guidelines to clarify how relevant provisions on EU legislation apply to food donation and to remove barriers, be they regulatory or operational, which hinder the donation of safe, edible food. Moreover, my services are working intensively on guidelines to facilitate the valorisation of so—called former foodstuffs as a safe resource for animal feed. There is huge potential to utilise former foodstuffs such as unsold bread or broken biscuits as animal feed. The guidelines are being finalised with experts from the Member States and we intend to publish them this autumn.  The Commission will also examine ways to improve the understanding and use of date marking by actors in the food chain, including consumers. We are currently carrying out further research and exploring, with Member States, food supply chain operators and consumers, possible ways to simplify date marking on food labels. This is no easy task. Should any changes be proposed in future, we would need to ensure that these, first, meet consumer information needs, second, can indeed make a contribution to food waste reduction, and – most importantly – third, would not put consumer safety at risk.  Finally, let me take this opportunity to thank the House and in particular the honourable Members directly concerned with our work on this report, which I am sure will help us make us significant progress towards our common goals to rescue food and help create a better world.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Madam President, there are obviously huge economic and environmental and social costs to food waste. Around 88 billion tonnes of food are wasted annually in the European Union with the associated cost estimated at EUR 143 billion. It is welcome that this issue is getting increased attention. But we can and should do more. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety was of course the lead committee on this file but I felt it was extremely important that the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development had a say also. In putting together the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development’s opinion on the report I want to concentrate on farm waste and how producers can be assisted in tackling it. Finding innovative solutions to the problem of food waste from the farm to the supermarket shelf, to the consumer is in everyone’s benefit. Firstly it goes without saying that no farmer wants to produce waste food. Farmers’ livelihoods depend on getting their produce to the market and loss of produce at farm level equates to loss of investment and income. Therefore farmers can be part of the solution here. Farmer-led initiatives can and have offered viable economic solutions and provide value for products which might otherwise go to waste as well as socially innovative projects such as gleaning and offering food that might otherwise go to waste to food banks. In Europe we import 40 million tonnes of feed yet we waste 89 million tonnes of food. So there is also potential for the use of former foodstuffs, by-products, in the food chain in feed production. But I also recognise the stress and need for increased traceability. The role of retailers also needs to be recognised. We will all have heard stories from producers in our constituencies about farmers having to search for secondary markets at short notice, even plough their produce back into the soil, because the supermarket does not accept their product. This can be for a number of reasons, from standards in terms of a product specification to cancelled orders owing to changes in consumer demand and over production as a result of requirements to seasonal demands. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my shadow rapporteurs on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and can I also congratulate the rapporteur on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Ms Borzan, on her excellent report.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank my colleague, Mrs Borzan, and all the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful discussions on this subject which has been close to my heart for a very long time. Globally, some studies show that a third of food is wasted each year. Across Europe, those thousands of tonnes could feed 200 million people. Food waste is ethical, but also environmental, social and economic nonsense. We need to strengthen consumer information, including their understanding of the dates indicated on packaging, on the one hand, and restore value to our food, on the other. Furthermore, research and innovation also have a role to play, both in limiting food waste and in food safety. It is also necessary to encourage the donation of unsold products via a reduction, or even elimination, of VAT, and by the establishment of agreements between economic players and charities to recover these unsold products. But to encourage donations, it will also be necessary to ensure that these food aid associations have the means to collect them, otherwise it would be a blow to the water. I proposed an amendment to the paragraph referring to ugly fruits and vegetables. Part of the waste actually results from the establishment of standards imposed by distributors on producers in order to meet consumer expectations. But I remain convinced that it is necessary to seriously analyze the consequences of these standards both on food waste and on farmers' salaries. However, promoting ugly fruits and vegetables is, in my opinion, more of a sleeve effect than a long-term solution. The supply of ugly fruits and vegetables is random; gold, to make a sector work, you need a sustainable offer.In addition, this paragraph asks to encourage and develop these markets, but what about the farmers who currently supply the fruit and vegetable distribution channels?Be careful not to introduce unfair competition.For me, the solution involves better education and better information for consumers, not to mention an analysis of the consequences of their requests and their behavior.I am nonetheless convinced of the importance of this report and of the need to give it broad support in order to send a strong message.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mrs. Dalli is quite right. Large amounts of food are lost every day in the various links of the food chain. The figures are indeed hallucinatory: worldwide the loss amounts to 1.3 billion tons of food per year, about a third of the total food production. In the EU, an estimated 88 million tonnes of food would be lost annually, which equates to 173 kg per person per year. It goes without saying that we have to put a stop to this. Wasting food is bad for people, the environment and the economy. Moreover, food waste is at odds with our ambition to switch to a circular economy, in which we are fully committed to preventing waste and trying to reuse or recycle precious raw materials as much as possible. That is why I endorse the priorities in this resolution: halve food loss by 2030, roll out a concrete action plan to achieve this goal, and focus strongly on awareness and prevention. The keys to success are undoubtedly the involvement of all players in the food chain and an important role for regional and local authorities so that tailor-made solutions can be delivered. Flanders, the nation that I represent here, is taking the lead and has already developed its own action plan to reduce food loss by 15% by 2020. All actors, from farm to fork, are represented in a chain consultation. Numerous interesting initiatives are being launched, such as the Chefs Charter of Horeca Vlaanderen or the Green Vent Scan. The donation of food is digitally facilitated via online platforms and apps. The expansion of the 0% VAT rate for the distribution of unsold foodstuffs also has a positive effect. In addition, consumers receive all kinds of tips, information is distributed about the best-before dates and “ugly” fruit and vegetables are once again making their appearance on the shelves. The mandatory collection and recycling of bio- waste and encouraging home composting are important in the fight against food waste.A recent visit with some colleagues to the Ecowerf composting plant in Leuven shows the enormous possibilities in this regard.In short: the fight against food waste is a matter for everyone, and governments must set a good example.Let's work on that together.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues! Our food waste topic today is an urgent issue that concerns us all. 53% of the food thrown away comes from private households. In this context it should not be forgotten that we in Europe do not all live in total abundance. Around 55 million Europeans cannot afford a full meal even every other day. Nevertheless, to illustrate: every European throws almost two kilos of food into the trash every week, and in addition there is the same amount of waste that is generated in the upstream area of ​​the food chain. The European Union has declared war on this waste. The aim is to cut food waste in half by 2030. So far, however, we have lacked the basic instruments for this, Commissioner. We therefore appeal in this report to come up with a uniform definition and measurement methods as soon as possible. That is the foundation on which we can design measures. So far we have 29 regulations, 10 directives, 14 documents from at least seven policy areas - you mentioned it - and we have to act as quickly as possible. Two topics are particularly close to my heart. First: Consumers are the key to success, which is why we need to create more awareness of the problem, bring nutrition education back to the fore, and make important information more accessible to consumers. Among other things, the shelf life must become more understandable. I only mention the two key words best before date and consumer date. Of course, we can rely more on new media and thus better reach the younger generation. Second, food donations must be simplified. For me that means that we have to see the food chain stakeholders as part of the solution and not as the cause of the problem.It is up to us to create a positive framework for donations and thereby activate voluntary commitment.With this report we are providing important impetus for this.I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs very much for the good cooperation.We have seldom been so closed in an own-initiative report.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, thank you to my colleagues for their excellent cooperation. I see it as downright criminal that, at a time when huge amounts of edible food are being wasted in the EU, for example, in 2014, 55 million people could not afford a decent meal than every other day, and the following year it was estimated that almost 119 million people were at risk of poverty and out of all systems of society. There is much to be done about food waste, but we need to define things first in a mutually agreed way so that Member States and stakeholders can measure it more accurately and develop ways to reduce waste and use the rest otherwise, for example by donating edible food to those who need it. Poverty-induced hunger can be alleviated with surplus food that has been found to be safe, but it means that surplus food must be made sensibly available to people. There is a lot of room for improvement in the food chain in general. In terms of kilometers food is transported to the product: an annual food and food products travel on our roads about a half-million-kilometer journey. On the way, you would have time to travel around the globe more than once, that is, to produce local food, if you want to invest in it.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Club. - Thank you, Mr. Chairman, Honorable Commissioner, I take this opportunity to remind you of a recent study by the Court of Auditors which showed that in addition to political will and the debate on food waste, the Commission has not shown much commitment to solving this problem. That is why I am glad to hear your words today, how you and other commissioners will work diligently on this, and I eagerly await the trialogue, because as a shadow rapporteur for the Greens, I have succeeded in introducing a binding goal for the European Union in food waste. In fact, will you show in that trialogue that commitment to side with Parliament and convince the member states that food waste is an economic, economic, social, environmental problem, so we can list as many as we want. And that moment, when we talk in the trialogue, be aware that on that day 55 million citizens of the European Union could not afford a quality meal, and we waste 180 kilograms of food per capita per year and send it to landfills. We send and create one environmental problem. And we know how weak individual Member States are still in achieving the goals that we ourselves have defined, and that the Commission has defined in the circular economy package in terms of reducing waste disposal by 2030. Of course, the burden should be borne by all, politicians, citizens and the economy. But one thing is certainly important, that it is crucial in our policies that we adopt that through innovation, through technology, we enable not only less food to be wasted but also that the packaging in which that food is packaged also does not end up in landfills it doesn’t happen to burn in incinerators because we are witnessing that by 2030, two million people a year could die from the consequences of actually burning waste. If we were to reduce food waste by 60%, the territory of agricultural land in the Member State of the Republic of Croatia would be spared from poor use. Thank you pretty.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the data on food waste in European Union are quite astonishing. Almost 88 million tonnes of food is being wasted in the EU each year, and a number of studies have shown that between 33% and 50% of the world food production is not consumed. Consequently, I concur that such waste is an issue of great importance, affecting both national and global food security. The rapporteur believes that a solution to this problem is a coordinated policy at EU level with the EU action plan for the circular economy laying the foundation, in conjunction with the Commission evaluating the relevant legislation to see if it is fit for purpose and identifying if there are gaps, overlaps or areas in need of clarification or further action. However, my party UKIP and I believe that an issue as great as this should be addressed at a global rather than a European level with the national parliaments of Member States monitoring wastage and food safety issues in their countries without the creation of further EU bureaucracy and legislation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, in my country, France, twenty kilograms of food waste are wasted per inhabitant each year. Apart from the additional financial cost, which represents between 110 and 150 euros per person, such a situation is not acceptable in a country where four million people benefit from food aid. I of course support this text, which insists on the need for a clear definition of food waste in order to be able to quantify it and limit it as much as possible. Likewise, it is more than urgent to ensure that citizens better understand the difference between the statements "to be consumed until" and "to be consumed preferably before", as misunderstandings could be the source of a problem. absurd waste. On the other hand, it is commendable that this report sees variable pricing based on deadline as an effective tool. Indeed, financial incentives are always preferable to a punitive approach. I also support the idea that supermarkets, but also local governments, must play a vital role in reducing waste. The latter are best placed to promote short circuits and local products, especially among young people. At the same time, it is essential to ensure that all food approaching the expiration date is donated to charity, which clearly is not yet taken for granted. Finally, this report does not emphasize enough the opportunities offered by new technologies. For example, some applications allow customers to buy unsold items from restaurants or businesses at a reduced price. These are, of course, prospects for the future, which beg to be exploited.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, thank you very much for the opportunity to address you on this particular subject. All UK citizens who have food waste caddies are very familiar with this initiative and obviously they will be watching, I hope, all of the developments that take place in terms of the debate this evening and the voting this week on this. As ever they will be looking at it somewhat critically. Why is the European Union actually doing this, and what does it actually imply and mean in terms of implications?  I think the negative that really needs to be addressed and voiced this evening is this issue again of European Union control on every aspect of the food chain, from animal health and welfare, packaging, crop selection, transport, consumption and waste disposal, and it is all about performance targets and does not address local issues. So, in short, the European Union is trying to take control of every issue, be it from farm to fork to bin, and I do not think that is the right way to go about it. I welcome what the rapporteur is trying to do, but I think at this stage it has gone too far in terms of just addressing numbers and meeting those targets. It is not actually looking at local Member State issues and how they need to manage and address what happens at the sovereign state level.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, according to UNICEF, almost one million and 400,000 children could die from malnutrition this year in Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen, while three million and 100,000 children under the age of 5 die of hunger each year. Every ninth inhabitant of the world goes to bed hungry, and according to FAO data, about one billion and 300 million tons of food are thrown away every year. This leads to the conclusion that the problem of hunger is not primarily a problem of food production, technology and raw materials, nor climate change, but above all a crisis of morality and a crisis of policies implemented both globally and within countries. Today, more than ever, we need new policies geared towards people, not profit. We need rational resource management and sustainable management. The European Union throws away 88 million tons of food a year, and in order to prevent food from becoming waste, we are in the process of adopting an action plan for the circular economy and I believe that one of the measures to reduce food waste can be stronger support for local agricultural production. short food supply chains. I am in favor of targeted social policies such as the abolition of VAT on donated food, as well as those aimed at supporting social self-service and humanitarian associations. However, the most important thing is to change the consciousness of politicians, who must show responsibility for the people entrusted to them. Thank you very much.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - Mr President, the data we know about food waste is shocking. 88 million tons of food were wasted in the European Union in 2012, and globally almost a third of food ends up in landfills. The real cost is huge because it reflects the costs involved in producing food with energy, water, transportation, fertilizers and everything related to the soil. Equally high are the associated costs: carbon emissions, water pollution, soil and ecosystem degradation. All these are consequences of overproduction. Food waste only stimulates this overproduction which, over time, diminishes the ability of agricultural soil to provide food for a growing population in the future. As my colleagues have said, it is also a moral and political issue, not just a food issue. Enormous amounts of food are wasted, while a very large number of Europeans, including children, are facing poverty and malnutrition. The resolution presented by the Committee on the Environment makes some important and practical proposals, and work has already begun on common definitions and methodologies for combating this phenomenon. I call on colleagues to support these proposals, as well as the mandatory measures proposed to be implemented at EU level that are needed to combat food waste throughout the food chain.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, I would like to agree with all of my colleagues in thanking Ms Borzan for this report. She chose a very challenging subject for a word-limited own initiative report but I think she has done a terrific job. And, for the record, having followed two British Members, both happened to be ladies this time, I would like to say that I think it is entirely not the case that this is not of use to all of us. It is extremely useful to share best practice, it is extremely useful to share benchmarking, not to repeat the reinventing of the wheel across 28 Member States. What is wrong with that? I think it is a terrifically good idea and there are lots of ideas in here. I compare it for example with a House of Commons report from the UK and so many of the things are along the same lines – similar thinking, the gathering of data, the use of data. It is all terribly important and I think this report really does a great job in bringing all of those threads together. I would just like to welcome very much what the Commissioner said about rethinking within the Commission on animal feed. I recognise why every time I meet somebody over about 70 they talk to me about how food used to be collected to be fed to pigs and chickens, etc. and I try painstakingly to explain to them why, for public health reasons, that had to be stopped. And they always kind of look at you a little bit blankly because clearly the use of food waste in animal feed would be a good move forward. So thank you, Commissioner, I really welcome your thoughts that that is being rethought through, because I do think that this House would welcome that so long as public health was adhered to. So thank you again and I look forward to seeing some of these ideas come to fruition.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - Everyone agrees that food waste should be avoided as much as possible. There are several ways to achieve this, but the primary responsibility for this naturally lies with the consumer. Clarity about best-before dates can help consumers in this regard. Recent research from Wageningen University has shown that if expiration dates on long-life products such as rice, pasta and coffee are omitted, this leads to 12% less waste. It would therefore be good for the Commission to seriously consider whether it is possible to expand the European list of products that are exempt from a best before date. Flexible regulations regarding food donation could also be interesting. However, we must be careful that the safety and quality of food is always a priority. Food safety must never be compromised. In addition, I am a strong supporter of initiatives whereby the government and parties such as catering companies and supermarkets work together to reduce food waste. We must encourage and welcome these promising initiatives. Where necessary, see whether laws and regulations can be amended without incurring entrepreneurs with unnecessary bureaucracy. That is why we must be careful not to implement European regulations without binding targets for food waste. This can actually have a demotivating effect. In addition, food waste should be addressed at national level. The European Union does not have to get involved in this right away by proposing legislation.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Food waste production is reaching alarming levels in the EU. We are talking about 173 kg per capita per year. The production and disposal of this waste eliminates up to 170 million tons of CO2. There is constant pressure to reduce emissions from all directions and in all sectors. We are talking about a new regulation of energy efficiency. We support organic, eco and similar labels to prevent the irreversible effects of consumption on the environment. At the same time, the average European throws away tens of kilograms of food a year, and this is not a sustainable situation. The world is burning because of our insatiable consumption. As it turned out, for example, with palm oil. The situation is that, thanks to our demand, we will devastate one part of the world and then throw things from the terribly produced substance into the trash in millions of tonnes and burn it for further emissions. Well, that's scandalous. That is why I very much welcome not only this report by my colleague Borzan, but also the circular economy package as amended by this institution. However, I would go even further. From the non-binding target of reducing the production of this waste by 50% by 2050, I would definitely make the target binding. It is quite clear that we cannot continue like this.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: - Mr President! Thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs Borzan. The food chain does not go from the store to the refrigerator, but from the field or the depths of the sea right up on the rubbish heap. We throw away huge amounts of food. If we are to cope with the climate and the world's population growth, we must become more resource efficient in all areas. Therefore, the fight against food waste must be a high priority in the EU. Food waste must be reduced and this week we are voting on a first step to reduce waste by 30% over eight years, and then by 50% in thirteen years. We must continue the hard work for healthier and more environmentally friendly agriculture, animal husbandry and fishing. We must avoid transporting food back and forth across the globe. The European Commission must act now. Why does the Commission not initiate legislation? All countries in the world have signed Sustainability Goal 12.3 on reducing global food waste. Therefore, it is incomprehensible to me that this responsibility is not taken at EU level. We need to get better at teaching our children the importance of not throwing away food, and we need to look at the labeling of products - is it possible to eat food after the best before date? We could also use the tax tool to make it profitable to donate unused food. Everything to avoid good food ending up in the dump. As unsustainable as it is to make food that is thrown directly on the landfill, it is just as unsustainable to fish up everything that moves, clean out the little you want and then throw away the rest. It's time for more fish in the oceans, more food in the stomach and less food at the dump. Thanks so much!

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that it is truly unacceptable that in times of economic crisis every citizen of the European Union can waste on average 173 kilograms of food every year and, on the other hand, if this is an average, it means that there are poor people who waste nothing, because they have little more than nothing, and therefore there are rich people who waste double or even much more than double these enormous quantities. We will support any proposal that seeks to reduce this waste, such as the progressive reduction of the price of food products as they approach, as their natural expiration approaches. On the other hand, at the same time, we believe that it is really unacceptable that in times of ecological crisis there is food waste; food has a negative impact on the environment when it is produced and it has a negative impact on the environment when it is wasted, because it becomes waste and therefore must be disposed of. Our recipe is very simple: prevention of food waste, incentives for conscious consumption and absolute ban on landfilling and incineration of any type of food waste.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: - Mr President, according to the FAO, approximately one third of the world's food production is wasted in the world. And something, of course, must be done. Many Member States are already acting; for example mine. There is a strategy called "More food, less waste", which is about coordinating the actions of the agents in the food chain and public administrations to reduce food waste.
