But the first thing we have to do is clearly define what is meant by food waste and establish a common methodology for all countries, clear and precise, before attempting to set mandatory targets to reduce waste. This must be taken into account very much, given that some Member States have already started to take actions and, probably, with different criteria. As I have said, it is premature and for this reason, precisely for this reason, it is premature to pretend to set compliance targets a priori without a clear definition and methodology and without obtaining data on the starting situation of each Member State. On the other hand, awareness, information and education campaigns must also be carried out, especially on the value of food, the consequences of its waste and the ways to reduce it. And, finally, I would like to point out that both prevention and waste reduction policies require the effort of all the actors involved in the food chain, in order to be more efficient. Thus, being able to limit losses and waste and reduce environmental pressures would be most desirable.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was very surprised to read, in a recent study, that if food waste were represented by a state, this would be the third largest producer of carbon dioxide on the planet, not to mention that in the world for every undernourished person two, at least, are overweight. Europe has committed, with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, to halve this which is one of the most unbearable economic, environmental and ethical contradictions, but to date nothing is foreseen in European legislation. So, point number one: insert the commitment to reduce waste by overcoming a regulatory vacuum, as Parliament asked in its position on the circular economy package and as it continues to ask with this important report by Mr Borzan. Two: to support the achievement of this goal with the specific actions that have already been mentioned, but also with a specific hierarchy for food, which privileges human consumption through donations. The waste is not only that of final consumption, but that throughout the chain, from agricultural production to food processing, from distribution to catering, and it is there that we must make it more convenient for companies to donate to those in difficulty rather what a waste. Finally, to encourage the use of organic waste that can no longer be donated as a secondary raw material for new products. So, the invitation I make here, both to the Member States and to the Commission, is to share this urgency that Parliament is also expressing with this further and important report, to find a solution starting with the circular economy package, today under negotiation. On these issues, which call into question the values ​​of solidarity and equity, Europe must be at the forefront.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: - Mr Chairman! I fully support Mrs Borzan's initiative to call on the Commission to take action against food waste. Safe and healthy food is a priority, but this priority must not ignore the economic aspect. 88 million tonnes of food worth EUR 150 billion a year go to the bin. It is also impossible to get over this priority ethically, when there are huge problems of malnutrition and hunger in the world. It is estimated that fifty percent of food waste comes from European households. They are the consumers, we are making this mess. We just don't understand the concepts of food shelf life. We do not distinguish the date of minimum durability from the date of use-by, so we throw it into the trash just in case. Taking the initiative and wide-ranging indications is the task of the plan that the Commission should submit. And finally, VAT. It is unacceptable that the donors who donate food to people in need should be subject to VAT. And it is not an excuse that some countries have found ways to circumvent the law. It needs to be normalized.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: - Thank you, Mr President. Every third pound of food spoils. In the EU, most food waste is generated by households. The solution can also be found up close: from each of us ourselves, the consumers. Food that ends up in a food basket puts a strain on the economy and the environment. It has been produced, packaged, transported and shelved completely in vain. Food waste raises the total cost of the entire food value chain. The climate impact of food waste accounts for about a quarter of the EU's annual CO2 emissions. That is a lot, and that means action needs to be taken. Consumers need help to succeed in reducing their food waste. The most important thing is to influence people’s behavior. The more concretely the benefit can be demonstrated to oneself and one’s close associates, the more likely people are to change their behavior. Of course, reducing food waste requires a lot of other measures in addition to a change in attitude. Action must be taken, including the whole retail chain. There must be a commitment to smart and cost-effective solutions to reduce losses. In anticipation of these innovations, each of us can launch personal disposal campaigns. First, by taking what you eat on the plate and buying what you consume from the store.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: - Mr President, by adopting the circular economy package we approved a non-binding target, that 30% in 2025 and 50% in 2030 that the rapporteur recalled, and we included a specific hierarchy for this waste.It is a positive step in the right direction, but I honestly believe that it is not enough.That we need binding targets, as has already been mentioned in this debate.Not only to urge change, but to make it possible, from farm to table - as the curator illustrated - through distribution.And we will only achieve this with a change in the system, with a sustainable and coherent production and consumption model, linked to demand and not to the interests of the markets.On the other hand, we need to better measure the losses in the primary sector, for example in agriculture, but this also requires moving away from the model of liberalization of quotas and quotas, with which we produce surpluses that are later discarded.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on a subject which is, I would say, a real scandal. Why? Because, from a social point of view, on the one hand, 10% of the population in Europe does not even have access to a quality meal and more than 23% is in precariousness and, on the other - it has been said - 88 million tonnes of food is wasted and a third of the food produced for human consumption is lost. So this is untenable, either from a social or an environmental point of view. We fight over at the COP21 and we see that agriculture represents a quarter of total water consumption, an area as large as China and about 10% of greenhouse gas emissions , and that all is not used. So yes, I welcome this report and I think we need to have binding targets, like for energy. It will go through sobriety. Our children need to know that food is not just any commodity. We must also be more efficient, which will require better technology, but also better information, because the difference between the words "to be consumed preferably before" and the expiration dates is very poorly understood by consumers. So I think a clarification is needed. We must also have a coherent CAP policy. How can we, on the one hand, create a common agricultural policy that promotes productivity and, on the other hand, want to eliminate food waste? It is therefore up to us, to Europe, to act, and I believe that this is a real European problem that must be addressed in the Member States to reduce this food waste.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! The figures we have heard today show it impressively: If we have to assume that 28% of the products that are grown on the field, that ripen there, that are harvested there, in reality never end up in the consumer's stomach, then we know: there is a problem here. It's a moral problem and it's a political problem. A moral problem when we know how many people in this world are starving who, as we heard today, cannot even afford to eat a decent meal every other day. A political problem because it is costly. Production also generates what we warn about everywhere, namely additional CO2 emissions. We heard it today: If food waste were a state, it would be the third largest state on the world after the USA and China. That means we have a very big challenge here. Of course, first of all we have to create education, awareness. But we also need framework conditions for how things are produced here. The previous speaker said: We must also change our agricultural policy. How often are we told as an argument in favor of using genetically modified material, pesticides, that we have to do this so that we can feed the world. If a third of the food we produce is disposed of, then there is no reason for me to continue this agricultural policy as it is today. We need a legal framework and we need the appropriate funds so that we can really cut this waste in half by 2030.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: - Mr President, I appreciate that we are re-addressing this very important issue in the European Parliament. Not only is food waste extremely unethical, as more than 88 million tonnes of food in Europe are thrown away every year in a situation where almost 800 million people in the world suffer from malnutrition, but it is also an unnecessary depletion of our resources. Although food waste occurs at all stages of the production process, the fact remains that households are responsible for the largest share of food discards, up to 53%. Therefore, it is up to each of us how we approach this phenomenon. We have a lot of good experience, first of all shopping appropriately for our consumption, storing food properly in order to prolong its shelf life and also through charitable projects to be able to share with those who need it. At the same time, measures need to be taken at Member State level to motivate restaurant operators or large food chains to engage in such projects.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Mr President, it is good to talk about food waste today in the plenary of the European Parliament; A report that finally raises the need for a change of model towards a more sustainable model that talks about waste generation, that talks about the destruction of nature, is positive. We have to change the guidelines and this report begins to talk about the necessary measures to avoid food waste, specifically the "Good Samaritan" legislation that serves to encourage, in some way, that surplus food ends up being donated - surplus food. supermarkets, restaurants, etcetera. I would like to make a couple of points in this regard. It is good that we talk about production limitations, but these production limitations have to be associated with the concept of food sovereignty, because what cannot be is that they do the same to us as with milk: do not tell us - to Spain - that we have to produce less milk so that our foreign milk market is invaded, because that does not make us more sustainable, it makes us poorer. And it is good that we talk about recycling, but we have to talk above all about a change in the economic model. As Gandhi said, on earth there are enough resources to meet the needs of all, but there are not so many to meet only the needs of some. So what is needed is to change the production model; it is necessary to change the model, the food production and distribution system.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: - Mister President! I am very pleased that the report makes it very clear that we need a very specific hierarchy of waste with regard to food waste, the primary objective of which is to avoid and reduce first. And there I would like to bring another aspect into the debate that has not yet been discussed: the Committee on Agriculture has strongly urged to invest in the energetic use of food waste and to create additional sources of income for farmers. I am glad that the Environment Committee did not give in to this pressure. The energetic use can be an option, but only if it takes place under clearly defined conditions. We disregarded that in Germany, for example. Not only were large biogas plants funded there, which then invest in residual materials such as liquid manure or leftover feed and bring them in, but maize is grown there, and 10% of our area is now used for purely energetic use, and I believe that energetic use on This waste hierarchy must end. Because we are not allowed to develop this usage into a business model. First people have to get to the food, and then we can give it to the animals and the environment and finally to the energy.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! We use energy, renewable raw materials to produce food, and perhaps the biggest problem is that since we are able to obtain roughly the same amount of plant and animal products every year, we think we can give up their economical use. In food production, water is taken, emissions take place and we impact the environment, but on the other hand, food waste is primarily an ethical problem. We cannot afford such wasteful resource management - food must not end up as waste. And here we don't even have complete statistics on how much food waste we produce in each country. We therefore need to develop a new approach, so thank you for this initiative. When we look at the scale of food waste, it is worth paying attention to the fact that not only food can be made from these resources, but also other products. After all, they are raw materials that can also be used for industrial processing. It has been repeatedly said in Parliament that biofuels should not be made from agricultural products as this is in competition with food production. But a question should be asked: if the scale of the waste is so large, does it not take some reflection? Finally, we should consider how to use processed foods during their shelf-life and whether or not to donate them, in line with this postulated Good Samaritan initiative, to charities such as food banks.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Mr President, first of all, my congratulations to Mrs Borzan on this ambitious and timely report. And the thing is, ladies and gentlemen, it is not ethical for one part of the world to throw away what another needs. We need a change in behavior - as has been said here - that involves all actors in the food chain. Because 60% of what is wasted in our homes is avoidable, which would save 565 euros a year or remove one in five vehicles from circulation, thereby reducing pollution. For this, we need a consistent labeling of food, which avoids the variation between 28 and 35 days in the expiration date that the same foods have in different places or that the time of this expiration depends on the market demand. We need packaging with adequate quantities for consumption, stimulate the reuse of food and modify the VAT Directive, which prevents donations from being exempted for food banks. We also need to work to change quality standards and thus avoid the numerous waste that is produced in food. These are, therefore, all ambitious and appropriate measures. For this reason, I consider that this report, in addition to being feasible, is clearly timely. Congratulations, Mrs Borzan!

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! In taking the floor in the debate on reducing food waste and increasing food safety, I would like to emphasize that the report's proposal to reduce this phenomenon by 50% by 2030 deserves support, especially as this waste currently affects 88 million tonnes of food per year, worth nearly 150 billion euro. In this situation, of particular interest is the amendment to the VAT directive proposed by the rapporteur, which would explicitly allow Member States to exempt food donations from taxation with this tax, as well as the possibility of financing from the European Aid Fund for the most deprived costs of collecting and transporting, storing and distributing food donations. Moreover, due to the fact that in Western European countries food wastage is at least five times greater than in Central and Eastern European countries, the main emphasis on counteracting food wastage should apply primarily to highly developed countries.

name: Stefan ECK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Food waste in the EU is getting more and more absurd, currently it is around 88 million tonnes per year. What a scandal is that! Agriculture, the food industry, commerce and of course consumers are responsible for this waste. But in view of the around 800 million people who suffer from hunger and the millions of children who die each year from the consequences of malnutrition, it is our duty to create the legal framework for more corporate responsibility, for consumer awareness-raising at national and European level to accomplish. But that alone is not enough. We urgently need measures on the production side because we are simply producing far too much food. Now we not only need cosmetic corrections to the upcoming CAP reform, we also need a fundamental rethink in the area of ​​subsidized overproduction. We need a paradigm shift in agricultural policy. It must finally stand on an ethically oriented and not just a profit-oriented foundation. Please, Commissioner, do your part for this among your colleagues! Thank you in advance for that.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, today we could talk about the fact that the circular economy is not limited only to goals of recycling or reducing waste that ends up in landfills; Today we could talk about the fact that food waste in the Union represents a CO2 footprint of close to one tonne for each European citizen. But today I want to talk about a point in this report that we could not allow ourselves to go unnoticed and, proof of this, is that whoever has made the least mention of it. I quote from the report: "Considering that, according to 2014 data, 55 million people, that is, 9.6% of the population of the Europe of [still] 28, could not afford a quality meal every other day" . I end the appointment. Mr President, Commissioner, it cannot be that, on the one hand, there is a food waste of 173 kilos per person per year and, on the other, we live with malnourished people because they cannot afford a good diet: there is no reason. For this reason, I want to highlight, first, the call that we make in this report to the European Commission to establish an action plan against food waste; second, the specific measures for the Member States to prevent such waste; and, third, tax exemptions for food donations. It is our duty to put the tools together and call on those who must develop and implement them so that together - institutions, national governments, civil society, citizens - we can begin to end malnutrition in Europe. And it is my duty also to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the transition to a circular economy is weak, much weaker without common European rules, to reduce food waste throughout the supply chain: production, distribution, consumption. It is not a question, I would like to say to my colleague who spoke earlier, of interfering with and hindering national initiatives, on the contrary, these must be supported, encouraged and coordinated, but a common European basis is needed. It is an illusion that this gigantic problem can only be solved by national measures, we must not put our heads in the sand. Reducing food waste is an urgent need. We are in an incredible paradox, other colleagues have said, one billion and three hundred million tons of food wasted, four times the amount needed to feed the 800 million undernourished men and women. But food waste is not only an unbearable injustice, a gigantic social inequality to be ashamed of, it is also a waste of raw materials, waste of land, waste of water, waste of energy, multiplication of waste and environmental damage. That is why, I repeat, it is a blow to the transition to a circular economy if we limit ourselves only to good debates. A legislative initiative from the European Commission is urgently needed.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Mr President, it is clear that we must reduce food waste at European level. The figures are outrageous, they have been repeated here during the debate. And that is why I agree, how could it be otherwise, in requesting reduction commitments between now and 2025 and 2030. But, yes, I would have liked it to be mandatory, and not simply as recommendations to the States , then we already know what happens. I also think that this report has very positive aspects but, like the whole Commission proposal on circular economy, it neglects the state of agricultural and livestock production. We continue in an uncontrolled model that tends to overproduction and the absence of decent wages in the European field. Meanwhile, in addition, we continue to feed free trade agreements with falling agricultural prices. Therefore, the only valid alternative I understand is to defend food sovereignty, short distribution circuits and organic farming within the European Union.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I left home at 5.30 this morning and arrived in here at 7.30 this evening, and this is the story for many MEPs. That is not very resource efficient, and that is something we need to tackle in the broader sense. At least we are trying to tackle the food waste, which is similar. The figures, which have been mentioned, actually are staggering: 88 million tonnes of food are wasted each year at a cost of EUR 143 billion; the food that is produced globally but not eaten uses a volume water equivalent to the annual flow of the Volga River in Russia and adds 3.3 billion tonnes of greenhouse gases to the planet’s atmosphere. At time we are talking about meeting the two degree target, this is something we really have to tackle and thankfully we are beginning to do so. Also, of course, we have signed up to the UN sustainable development goals, and that is about halving the per capita food waste at the retail and consumer level. I was glad to hear the Commissioner mention the necessity for a reliable method to measure food waste, and this is something I welcome the report. Also the ‘best before’ and ‘use by’ dates. I am beginning to wonder: is there a need for a best before date? Maybe the simple thing would be to abolish it. Food is either safe or it is not, the ‘use by’ date would be proper and that would help to end the confusion. This is a major topic and I look forward for further development in the future.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, food waste is an unacceptable scandal of our time, as this report denounces. In fact, if on the one hand there is the need, in the coming years, to increase food production by 70 per cent, to feed a growing population, on the other hand in the world one third of the food produced is wasted, of which 80 per one hundred would still be consumable, in Europe 180 kilos per capita. Land, water and fertilizers are also wasted with food thrown away, not to mention the greenhouse gas emissions that are necessary to produce it. Reducing food waste by 50 percent by 2030, as envisaged in the package approved by Parliament on the circular economy, requires the commitment of everyone, producers, retailers, restaurateurs, businesses, individuals and families. 42 percent of food waste in Europe occurs within the walls of the home, a cost of over 500 euros per year per family. Let's start from home to promote a more sustainable development model from a social, environmental and economic point of view, through waste prevention campaigns and by encouraging food donations of unsold food.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I have listened very carefully to the debate of my colleagues and I must more or less say that I agree with what has been said here. Most of us here describe the gigantic proportions of the phenomenon and the problem of food waste. A number has been dropped here, which I will also repeat, because in such a case the repetition of some numbers is very important. 88 million tonnes of food is an annual waste in the EU. It's a really extraordinary number. The problem was described here both from an ethical point of view, where many people on this planet have nothing to eat, and from an economic point of view, and especially from an ecological point of view. It indicated how enormous the costs we have to be to produce the food, but also to dispose of it afterwards. I am therefore glad that this is material that points to this problem, but of course this material needs to be put into practice, and here I call on the Commission, the Commissioner, to do everything possible so that there is a concrete action plan that will bring concrete things. E.g. food donation tax solutions. I think this is very important, because there can be a clear tax incentive for residents, businesses and businesses to donate food that they do not use. There is a clear description of how households should behave, such as home composting. That is something I am also dealing with, so please put this plan into practice.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, food waste is an absurd paradox of modern times. On the one hand, there is the need to increase food production by 60-70 percent to feed a growing population, on the other hand over a third of the food produced is wasted in the world, of which 80 percent is still consumable. This waste is all the more illogical the more waste production, the environmental crisis, impoverishment and malnutrition increase. However, a problem that affects heterogeneous areas requires action on several fronts. Waste concerns all the steps that bring food from the field to the table. It is necessary to work on the consumption and production habits of individual communities on a regulatory level, but also through a capillary work of information. Secondly, surplus food must be recovered and destined for human consumption, supporting the bodies that carry out social assistance activities. However, all these actions must start from a common definition of food waste, to launch reliable systems capable of monitoring how much is wasted because, as someone has already said, the most dangerous type of waste is the one we are not able to recognize.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I actually identify with most of the views of my predecessors, my colleagues. I would like to point out that, of course, each of us should be ashamed of our lives if we open a refrigerator and have to throw something out of it. Knowing how many millions of people on the planet are starving. Undoubtedly, it is a question of thrift, our own personal approach to resources, or to their production, and of course in the case of some kind of destruction or irreversibility, and we should be aware of this in our personal approach. "Enlightenment, enlightenment, enlightenment!", He wants to call out, of course, knowing how food is wasted on a daily basis. We should also say that there are also problems at EU level, because I do not know how many of you know, but there is a certain standardization in the field of food and some apples, if they do not grow to a certain size, so they can not go directly to the customer. into that secondary production. At the same time, it has nothing to do with the nutrition and nutritional value of such an apple. It is simply an artificial rule set by the EU, so we should reach into our own conscience in this as well. In any case, I welcome the tools, the incentives that are mentioned in that report. I think they are going in the very right direction, but I also want to warn against trying not to interfere too much in paternalistic lives. We have to talk about it, we have to show enlightenment as much as possible, but to enter people's lives directly with sharp regulations, I would defend myself a little against that.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: - Mr President, it is important to note that in 2010, for example, one million people died of hunger and malnutrition and, in addition, three million people, three times more, died of obesity. More people in the world are dying from overeating than from undereating. 2.1 billion people are overweight and 793 million people are malnourished. So that some have more resources sickly, others die because they lack them. In addition to this, FAO identified that about a third of the food produced annually is directly lost and wasted. The misuse of resources is responsible for suffering that is absolutely preventable in the world in which we live. The paradigm is no longer growth, but efficiency and sufficiency. This report points out interesting and consequent solutions that range from organizational systems to those of food production and resource redistribution. It is an excellent report, necessary and urgent, for which I congratulate the rapporteur.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! It is right to try to do something about food waste. Food is a valuable commodity, and if food is wasted, it is incredibly expensive, because we don't just waste a specific food, but everything that has been put into the cultivation and production of this food: soil, water and of course energy , Fertilizers, sprays etc. It is not only expensive, it is also environmentally harmful. Because it is harmful to the climate if we produce much more than we ultimately consume ourselves, because we simply throw away a large part of what we produce. And of course it is extremely ethically questionable, above all against the background of the fact that the world population is growing so rapidly, the arable land cannot be increased and we have to think about how we can use the available land Feed the world and not just ourselves. The problem we have when we deal with the topic of “How do we avoid food waste?” Is that there is no internationally valid definition - not in Europe, and obviously not internationally either. And unless there is such a definition, it will be very, very difficult to determine how much the individuals in the food chain contribute to this food waste. We must be careful not to confuse the loss that arises in agricultural production with waste. There are inevitable crop losses, and there are also almost inevitable storage losses due to insects and fungi. One could certainly get a grip on this through the use of genetic engineering. But that is mostly not really wanted in Europe. And of course you can't do it in the processing either Process 100% of a piece of fruit or a vegetable. There, too, there is always waste, and that is more likely to be attributed to loss than to waste. But one thing is clear: the main culprit is actually ourselves, we consumers. I count myself among them. We are not sacrosanct and we are not always the victims. We have to realize that the best before date does not mean that I have to throw away the food. This is what the use-by date is for. But there is a lack of information about this, and this is where our Member States at home are called upon. But we also need to have information at home in the Member States about the value of a food itself. Because people are so urbanized nowadays, including in Europe, they no longer have any access to the actual value of food. Food is valuable - many people in the world who are in bad health know that. But we forgot. I call on the Member States to finally take action and re-teach the children how valuable food is.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, food waste is the deepest contradiction, the most unbearable paradox of our time. It is the figure that also represents our inability to address one of the most serious social injustices. If we think about the living conditions of millions of people, if we imagine, for a single moment, that malnutrition and hunger steal the future from the most precious human capital, boys and girls, then the theme of inequality, imbalance and opportunities intersect with other issues, with the themes of the future of the planet and our continent, with the theme of the defense of the soil, the limitation of its consumption, climate change, hydrogeological instability, natural disasters, in a vision of the waste cycle. It is a crucial, ethical issue, yes, but also a vision of development and growth. The reflection that the report offers us is an excellent working tool, it is an objective with respect to which time cannot and must not be an irrelevant variable.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! Here, too, various rates, quantities, thousands of millions of tonnes have been said several times during the debate, but let us acknowledge that wasted food in Europe can also be expressed in euros, expert estimates put it at EUR 140 billion a year, which we throw away as food. This is, by the way, the same as the European Union's own annual budget, so it is an insane amount. However, there is a phenomenon that I would like to draw to the attention of the Commissioner, and it is in Hungary, in my country, that in addition to social degradation, the rate of food waste is still increasing. This is probably due to the fact that poor people can only buy very perishable food, fast-deteriorating food. In Hungarian, I wanted to draw attention to the fact that the social situation is also important for food waste.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, this is not the first time we have dealt with food waste in the European Parliament.I think that's right, because we should appreciate food.However, as a doctor, I would like to call for some caution.Even with the best of intentions, we must not allow some EU citizens to be exposed to a higher health risk simply because they are in poverty.That is why I would like to ask you, dear colleagues, to ask yourself, in any specific proposal of a measure in spirit: would I give such food to my child or to my parents?Because only if we ask ourselves this question can we reduce food waste so that we do not endanger public health and, above all, preserve the human dignity of those who depend on this type of food aid.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, food waste is estimated at $ 1.7 trillion a year. This is what many here call food waste. At the same time, 793 million of our fellow human beings are malnourished worldwide. 700 million people live below the poverty line. 23.7% of the European Union's population, 118 million, are currently at risk of poverty. At the same time, in 2050 we will have 9.7 billion inhabitants. The question, then, is how to address the issue of poverty. And this is tackled by having another model, a fair distribution of the wealth produced, because both wealth is produced and food is produced capable of nourishing all our fellow citizens. So we need a different policy, a fair distribution of wealth.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, the countries of the European Union are over-consuming and wasting food. The tragedy is that millions of tons of these foods are either thrown away or destroyed, even polluting the environment, and could be used to feed the millions of malnourished and starving people in Third World countries, as well as also meet the needs of the European homeless and the unemployed and other poor. Unfortunately this does not happen. On the contrary, in Greece, when the party to which I belong, the Golden Dawn, with offers from MEPs, MPs, members and friends, raised money and bought food that it distributed to hungry Greeks, the government criminalized this activity. In other words, if someone wants to give food to hungry Greeks, he risks being in prison. This, as you can see, is not just a political, but a moral, mental and emotional perversion, and for that very reason we cannot be optimistic that we will find a solution to this serious problem.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - It is unsustainable that the EU always generates as much as 88 million tonnes of food waste, while 55 million Europeans cannot afford a quality meal every other day.More than half of food waste is generated by households, and of course the whole process and process of the food chain gives its share.But it is, of course, also the public sector, even one that could use and dispose of less wasted food with better planning.So I think it’s time to consider that the most vulnerable groups, such as schools, kindergartens, hospitals, nursing homes ... to exempt this from the public procurement system when ordering food, because then we can really have locally grown food.Above all - of course - we will also avoid discarded food, which is practically unacceptable in the 21st century.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: - Madam President, I think it is time for us to make further progress on avoiding food waste.After all, up to 55 million people only have hot food every other day.We know that 88 million tonnes are discarded a year in the EU and that 173 kg is wasted by every single person a year, which means that we need to look at how we evaluate this, and it is up to the Commission to set up a single commission to knowgo further and compare individual Member States.It is outrageous that charities that want to distribute food provided to them by restaurants or large chains have VAT imposed on this activity for food donated in this way.That must end.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I have joined this debate, although I think that concrete solutions to prevent more food waste must be taken by the Member States.Nevertheless, we can learn from each other at EU level and also coordinate our activities.From the motion for a resolution, I consider it very important that the EU recommends, addressing how to prevent food waste and how to save food.It has already been said here that up to 30% of food in the EU is simply disposed of, discarded.I think that the goal of reducing food waste by 50% by 2030 as a non-binding goal is nice, but we need to see how it will help those who do not have food.I think that's missing from those goals.So we should focus in this direction.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - I was recently the rapporteur for this document in the CONT committee, and we came to the conclusion that the beginning is actually wrong.We want to deal with the hen, but we don't deal with the eggs.Why is food wasted so much?Because the EU gives an incredible amount of money for absolutely unproductive food production.Let's look at agriculture, it's one scam next to another.Where is the most cheating in the EU?Right in agricultural policy and let's see where the money goes and where food is produced and how.I think that the whole strategy needs to be changed.It has been said here that 88 million tonnes of food are wasted a year, but it is not said here that it is EUR 143 billion.It is the entire annual budget of the EU.So if we want to change something, we have to start here.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members have listened closely to this very interesting debate and I am grateful to this House for taking such an active interest in this important issue. May I say a few words? First of all, the Circular Economy package published in 2015 includes European Union level initiatives needed to support implementation of the food-based prevention programme by all actors through the whole food value chain. The proposal for revising the Waste Framework Directive requires Member States to reduce food waste at each stage of the food supply chain, monitor food waste level and report back on the progress made in preventing food waste. But I would like to mention a couple of points which were raised in the debate. First of all, Mr Škrlec mentioned the European Court of Auditors’ conclusions. The Commission cannot agree with these conclusions and regrets that the works done together with Member States since 2012 has not been fully recognised. We have identified the most efficient actions to take at EU level to combat food waste and want to remain truly ambitious. Given the multifaceted nature of food waste prevention, we have sought to engage both with private actors and public entities through all relevant fora, including expert groups with Member States and various consultative groups with stakeholder participation. This inclusive approach resulted in the Integrated Action Plan to tackle food waste adopted by the Commission as part of the Circular Economy package in 2015. Moving forward, the Commission will continue to strengthen its supporting efforts in the European Union Member States, notably through the European Union Platform on food losses and food waste, bringing together both public and private interests. Launched in 2016, the platform will support all actors in defining measures needed to prevent food waste, share best practices and evaluate progress made over time. I would like to strengthen, of course – some mentioned mandatory targets for food waste reduction. But the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals to halve global per capita food waste by 2030 is our food waste target, so no additional aspirational target was deemed necessary. We need to measure food waste consistently before binding targets can be proposed at EU level. The Commission’s proposal for revising the Waste Framework Directive requires Member States to measure food waste once again and to use indicators and targets set at national level to monitor progress in food waste prevention. Some mentioned definition of food waste. Food and waste are already defined in the EU regulatory framework, and an additional legal definition of food waste is not necessary. What really matters is a clear description of the material which constitutes food waste at each stage of the food supply chain. The Commission is therefore elaborating a methodology that will illustrate, in the light of EU definition of food and waste, which material may be quantified and measured as food waste, taking into account, amongst others, exemptions as defined in the Waste Framework Directive, and the definition proposed by the European Parliament will be further discussed internally within the Commission and with Parliament and Member States to ensure a satisfactory outcome. Some of course also raised questions about food donation. Food donation is local by nature: food which is available for donation has to be collected and redistributed to charities in a very short time in order to avoid any possible issue of food safety and ensure that food reaches those in need. For this reason, Member States and their local authorities are those best placed to directly intervene in this issue. The EU food donation guidelines seek to address the specific issues and obstacles encountered by Member States and stakeholders which need to be addressed at EU level. By focusing on better implementation of existing EU rules, the EU guidelines on food donation will support Member State authorities and stakeholders in ensuring the redistribution of safe, surplus food to those in need. Of course, also Mr Piecha and some others mentioned issues on VAT. Value added tax is governed at EU level by the EU directive and must be implemented in international law. VAT legislation can sometimes have implications for food donation, and the Commissions has worked actively with the Member States to clarify how VAT rules apply to food donation. In line with the guidelines agreed by the VAT committee, the Commission recommends that, in the determination of VAT for the donation of foods, the value of those goods should be adjusted according to the circumstances and the state of the goods at the time of donation. The Commission considers that, when food donations are made close to the ‘Best before’ date or the goods are not fit for sale but can be safely consumed, these circumstances should be taken into account by Member States when determining the VAT due – which could even be zero. Changes in the VAT Directive are not being considered. In its 2011 communication on the future of VAT, the Commission set out its policy to make the system simpler, more efficient and robust. A broadening of the tax basis important in achieving the goal set in producing new exemptions would run counter to the policy. You mentioned questions about better use of date marking. The Commission is working actively on this issue and initiated in 2016 a new study on date marking practices to help inform its work. It is important to promote a common understanding and use of date marking amongst all actors. This study will investigate how date marking is utilised by food business operators and by regulatory authorities and possibly-related impact on food waste. Outcomes of the study will help inform future policy-making. Any future changes to EU rules must meet consumer information needs, ensure food safety and make a meaningful contribution to food waste. Let me conclude by expressing again my gratitude to Ms Borzan and the shadow rapporteurs. The report, as well as your views and opinions expressed today, will, of course, be given due consideration by myself and by my services. We will continue to work together with our partners in the Member States and stakeholders towards our common goals, remove needless waste of food, and save our resources. I am very happy to present this report – in autumn, for example – to our Food Waste Platform and discuss those issues in more detail.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: rapporteur. - Thank you, Madam President. Dear colleagues, it is our job, our main job, for the European Union to work for the people. And it is precisely this topic, about reducing food waste and increasing food donation, that is an opportunity for the European Union to express itself. I would like to emphasize and express my great satisfaction with the fact that this report was adopted unanimously by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. We ask the Commission and the Member States to engage on this issue because this is a topic that is extremely important to our citizens, it is important to our farmers, it is important to our traders, and it is most important to those who need food, ie the hungry. Tonight's debate showed that Parliament is united on this issue and we will closely monitor the executive as they implement what we are proposing in this report. In conclusion, I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs, Mrs Angélique Delahaye, Marko Demesmaeker, Ulrike Müller, Merja Kyllönen, Davor Škrlec, Piernicola Pedicini, Jean-François Jalkh and all other colleagues who, with their amendments and their contribution tonight, the report looks like this today. Thank you very much.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - Achieving the goal of reducing food waste by 30% by 2025 and by 50% by 2030 (compared to 2014) cannot be achieved without the involvement of all actors in the food supply chain and without relevant analyzes on the causes of this waste, and identification of the food sectors where the greatest waste of food is registered, in order to identify solutions to prevent it. I consider the rapporteur's proposal to involve national authorities and partners in the field of information campaigns to help consumers understand the labels "best before" and "use by" to be beneficial. . In this context, I consider the involvement of the EU Platform on Food Loss and Food Waste to support the development of consumer information and education programs on food, to facilitate the cooperation of local stakeholders in initiatives to prevent food waste and donation. as well as the evaluation of good practices already implemented in different Member States, in order to better define effective tools to reduce food waste.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. - Food waste affects the entire food supply chain, so we should all take appropriate steps to reduce it effectively. Cooperation at both EU and Member State level is essential due to the complexity of the problem and the need to coordinate policy on waste, food safety and information, as well as in the areas of economy, research and innovation, environment, agriculture, education and social policy. In my opinion, an extremely important issue raised in this report is the regulation of the provision of food donations to people in need, and in particular the proposal to explicitly permit the exemption of food donations from taxation, as the current outdated provisions do not really meet the needs of the modern world. At the same time, I hope that measures to reduce food waste will go hand in hand with increasing the level of food safety, which must, however, remain a priority.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! The numbers on food waste are staggering, especially considering how many millions of people are malnourished or starving today. I believe that it is the moral and political responsibility of the European Union, one of the richest and most prosperous communities in the world, to reduce the huge amount of food thrown away every year. Based on all this, the report of the Committee on the Environment is very important and timely. One of the key objectives of the decision adopted today is to facilitate the work of non-governmental and church organizations involved in food donation, as donating unsold food throughout the supply chain not only results in a significant reduction in food waste, but also helps those in need. I am very pleased that the plenary report contains my amendment encouraging the use of the funds provided by the European Union's Food Aid Program, the FEAD, to deliver surplus food. In many regions, especially the disadvantaged ones, the biggest challenge is to deliver existing food to those in need and to set up and operate the right logistics. There is also a need to promote good practice in the Member States which excludes the responsibility of the donor for food donated in good faith and suitable for consumption at the time of donation, of course with full respect for food safety rules.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: written. - (FI) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, reducing food waste is not just about avoidable CO2 emissions - an estimated 170 million tonnes of food waste - or a waste of resources, but also, in particular, how we can feed the entire world in the future. It is not possible to dramatically increase food production, so attention must be paid to food that disappears from the chain. Personally, I hope that the issue will be looked at as holistically as possible. As an example of this, I see that, for example, negligence in animal welfare should be counted as a loss: the death of farm animals due to ill-treatment, inadequate care or other negligence should be counted as “loss”. Information enables action, and in solving the problems of our food production, that information must be as comprehensive as possible. It is also important to have a debate about our eating habits, as one of the biggest problems is the growing consumption of meat worldwide. I am calling for a fundamental change of thinking, in which we would move towards a comprehensive food policy that integrates all stages of food production within a single framework.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - The reduction of food waste is a moral obligation of a developed economy such as that of the European Union. Food waste occurs throughout the entire food production and supply chain, and all stakeholders have the responsibility to avoid and reduce the problem, starting with agricultural productions. Short food marketing channels can be an effective way to reduce crop losses, because productions linked to nearby consumption centers are more in line with real demand and crop losses are lower. In addition, these marketing channels structure the territory, consolidate the population and are an opportunity to create employment in a sector lacking generational change. The relocation of large production centers contributes to increasing CO2 emissions due to excess mechanization, the long distances that separate them from the consumption centers and the compulsory packaging increase losses when they are discarded. Local zero kilometer productions - or proximity - are the complement to the food supply chain with the lowest generation of crop waste, and the financial mechanisms of the CAP should widely promote their advantages.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - While some people (around 800 million people globally) barely have anything to eat, others can afford to shed pounds regularly, generating unprecedented, immoral and unethical food waste. As such, all stakeholders (institutions, organizations, households, industries, traders, distributors, research institutes, etc.) must contribute to combating food loss and reducing waste. The United Nations Sustainable Development Goal of halving food waste by 2030 can be achieved through the combined effort of all stakeholders in this phenomenon with a major negative impact on the environment and a holistic approach to all relevant Union policies. and Member States. Reducing waste and improving food security can be the direct result of changing the consumption behavior of the population, through a process of accountability of each individual, in this regard, information and persuasion being absolutely necessary. Limiting food losses can be achieved by using economic and fiscal incentives to facilitate the donation of safe and edible food. A clear definition of food waste also leads to its recovery as a safe resource for animal feed.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: In written form. - Food waste is a global problem, with the FAO estimating that approximately one third of all food produced in the world is lost or wasted each year. Within the EU alone, 88 million tonnes are wasted annually, equivalent to 173 kg of food waste per person. The production and disposal of this waste leads to the emission of 170 million tons of CO2 per year, ie. 4.5 kg of CO2 is released into the atmosphere per kilogram of food produced, costing the economy 143 billion euros. Combating food waste depends on all actors in the value chain, but consumer behavior has the greatest effect, as households generate the largest share of food waste (53%). Consistent measures are therefore needed at European and national level to raise consumer awareness of the quality of food and ways to prevent food waste. Social innovation, the creation of online platforms and the provision of tax incentives for food donation are also appropriate measures in this direction. The future CAP can play an important role in combating food waste by including this dimension in second pillar measures to promote the dissemination of good practice among Member States.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Tiziana Beghin, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the evaluation of external aspects of the functioning and organization of customs, as a tool to facilitate tradeand fight against fraud (2016/2075 (INI)) (A8-0162 / 2017)

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as you all know in Europe there are no borders between the various countries, but only a large common border for all goods arriving from outside. The rules for crossing it should be the same everywhere, but in some places this border is weaker than in others and this situation creates a distortion of commercial traffic from abroad and a detriment to the financial resources of the European Union. The resolution of which I am the author is a parliamentary document which puts this situation on paper and was prepared with the invaluable contribution of fellow rapporteurs for opinion and shadow rapporteurs in the INTA committee, whom I want to thank everyone. Madam President, there are European ports where customs controls are rigorous and careful, others where they are less so. This situation creates unfair competition between shippers, port administrations and states, which Europe cannot tolerate. Investigating I found various types of distortion. There is the case, for example, in which the same European legislation is respected, but applied in a different way between different countries. There are some ports that run on the thread of the legality of European standards and there are also those that just do not respect the rules, enjoying, for certain periods, the connivance of a part of the national authorities. An example is the gigantic scandal that broke out a few months ago, when it emerged that tons of Chinese counterfeit goods had crossed the European border into the United Kingdom and then poured without controls into France and Italy, where they caused losses of 4 billion euros in VAT. not collected, not to mention the prejudice to the entry of the European Union, which amounts to approximately 2 billion euros of lost customs duties collected due to the lower declared value. This situation undermines the foundations of European trade policy. When we negotiate free trade treaties, in when we tell citizens that they don't have to fear products that are dangerous to health and the environment, we need to be sure that we can deliver on this promise and that we can effectively control goods entering Europe. Unfortunately, this is not the case because Europe allows some countries to apply the rules differently or to turn a blind eye to part of Community law. This is why in the resolution we ask for an intervention by the Commission to ensure the harmonization of controls and the uniform application of the law, to identify differences in treatment between economic operators, to continue the path of computerization and interoperability of databases at European. We also ask the Commission to measure the impact of these different customs practices on inbound and outbound trade flows and to work in the WTO to promote the implementation of the international agreement on trade facilitation and finally to cooperate on customs matters. with the main commercial partners. Ladies and gentlemen, in order to write this resolution, I met with operators from many ports in Europe and Italy, collected their testimonies and brought their concerns to Brussels. For this I would like to thank all the people I met in the area and, in particular, the Customs Agency, the port authorities, but also the freight forwarders and terminal operators of Genoa, Trieste, Taranto, Palermo and Gioia Tauro and, last but not least, the health and phytosanitary offices that have lent their contribution. Finally, a special thanks goes to the Guardia di Finanza, the police, all those European civil and military forces that carry out customs control activities at the borders. I am very keen to thank them and to tell them that my resolution aims to highlight the legislative gaps between our countries, but in no way wants to question the excellent work that these forces are doing for the safety of goods on our territory.I hope that the Commission will follow the recommendations we have formulated, both for the protection of European citizens and for the protection of shippers, economic operators and port activities, but also to protect competition and to protect the dignity of commercial policy..

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the customs union, which celebrates its 50th anniversary next year, is at the core of the EU. Vigilance and constant effort are needed to cope with ever new challenges to its functioning. They concern the safety and security of EU citizens and come with new trade patterns like e—commerce. Let me briefly refer to some of the points raised in the report. First, on governance, in its communication of December 2016 on developing the customs union and its governance, the Commission outlined a strategic way forward. Stronger partnership between EU institutions and Member States, between customs and other border authorities, and between customs and trade, is a major priority. The Commission will report biannually to Parliament on the implementation of this strategy.  On uniform application, harmonised customs rules and electronic data exchange and processing are essential to the uniform application of the customs codes throughout the Union. In consultation with stakeholders, the Commission is preparing the necessary guidance.  On IT systems, we are working hard with Member States towards full integration of customs IT systems. In the meantime the transition will have to be properly managed. IT systems are also needed to support our customs cooperation with third countries. On customs simplification and controls, we are committed to developing customs simplifications in combination with risk—based controls. This is reflected in the legal provisions of the Union Customs Code (UCC) and in the EU strategy and action plan for customs risk management. We are also reflecting this position in our negotiations of international agreements to strengthen both trade facilitation and customs cooperation on controls.  E—commerce and rapidly increasing volumes of small shipments are a major challenge for authorities. We are working with Member States, partner countries, international organisations like the World Trade Organisation, World Customs Organisation, and traders to find innovative solutions. Duty and tax evasion and avoidance are a major issue. We must develop coordination between customs and tax authorities and the relevant IT infrastructures with a view to improving the effectiveness of controls as well as accelerating trade. On customs enforcement of intellectual property rights, the entry of counterfeit goods into the EU remains a major challenge. We have legal instruments in place. However, we need to redouble our efforts, in particular when it comes to closer cooperation between customs and the police and the implementation of risk management. On customs infringements and sanctions, I would take this opportunity to thank the Committee on International Trade for its support in the directive on the common framework for customs infringements and sanctions, which is crucial for uniform application of customs legislation and for respect of our WTO obligations.  Finally, I would like to confirm the Commission’s continued commitment to working closely with the Parliament so as to ensure that EU customs policy is effective, proportionate and fit for purpose, both within the EU and at international level.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur on the well—structured report and also thanks to Commissioner Dombrovskis for the detailed information.  The role that customs services play in the global trading environment, coping with the damage done by the illicit trade to the formal economy is indisputable. Illicit activities have a detrimental impact on economies in terms of growth, jobs, foreign investment and integrity of markets. At the same time they generate large sums for transnational organised crime. In order to eliminate the negative influence, the quality and performance of customs control on the transit of goods, particularly at ports and borders, is of high priority. It is necessary to ensure that there are homogenous control techniques among Member States for filtering at ports and borders by promoting modern risk management best control strategies. Inclusion of anti-fraud clauses in trade and investment agreements is necessary in order to protect the financial interests of the Union. We need closer customs cooperation, both within the Union and with third countries, as well as an effective sharing of statistical information related to EU import controls. Thus, in addition to preventing damage to the economy we will protect the health and safety of consumers, limiting the risk to societies and markets.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President! Trade policy and customs policy are two unequal sizes, but it is important that both work and that they can work together. We live in a world where we have a large international trade and that is why we are dependent on our customs authorities and that they also work the same within the EU. The customs authorities play a significant role in how the provisions of both the multilateral and bilateral agreements are administered. It is important that we have a uniform enforcement of the rules across Europe, so that there is a uniform and effective enforcement at European level. Unfortunately, that is not how it looks today. That needs to be fixed! It must therefore not be the case that there is speculation and cheating with the rules, so that you can send the goods to the ports where the rules are not properly enforced. No one in Europe benefits from non-enforcement of rules and weight-loss scams. On the other hand, we must also make sure that the rules that companies have can be understood and that they are as little bureaucratic as possible. For the EPP Group, it has been important for us to have a “level playing field”, the same rules of the game, around our ports, and it has also been important for us to simplify the rules that companies must work according to.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, I will begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her magnificent work and on incorporating most of my contributions. The customs union is undoubtedly one of the first achievements of the Union, but it is not over: we are far from achieving an adequate harmonization of customs controls. In some sectors, economic operators look for European ports that establish lower inspection and control and sanction requirements, allowing the entry into our markets of products that do not comply with European or environmental or phytosanitary requirements and, of course, allowing the entry of counterfeit products and illicit goods. And these divergences are allowing not only unfair competition with our industry but also between European ports, by penalizing those who demand greater requirements and controls, and are causing market distortions, trade traffic diversions and, of course, an environmental impact. negative. This situation, I think we all agree that it is inadmissible. And it is avoidable and depends on the political will to defend our Union. The European Commission, the Council, the Member States have to do whatever is necessary to achieve a truly perfectly harmonized customs union. And the European Parliament too. So we are here, bringing this magnificent resolution, introducing concrete measures to help solve this problem. The European Union effectively needs to harmonize the inspection criteria and the number of controls at customs; you need to establish indicators to assess customs practices. And I argue that it is necessary to ensure that we have a European control body that truly guarantees harmonized treatment at the Union's ports of entry: it cannot be such a complicated process that we continue to experience the situation that is taking place . Necessary also improve coordination between customs authorities, OLAF and EUIPO, and harmonize sanctions and strengthen cooperation to ensure the protection of intellectual property rights.Illicit trade - we have already said - also contributes to the financing of criminal organizations dedicated to terrorism, money laundering, drug or arms trafficking.In conclusion, the European Union needs harmonized controls, inspections and sanctions.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, this report calls for harmonisation of controls at all points of entry into the customs union and for increased surveillance and security measures. I want to talk to you about Ireland post—Brexit. There are 277 roads crossing the border in Ireland. This is not counting farms that straddle the border nor houses where you enter the front door on one side of the border and leave it through the other side. Now during the conflict in Ireland cross—border smuggling was a daily occurrence. Among the achievements of the Good Friday Agreement was that smuggling was dramatically reduced. If the might of the British military could not close the border, EU customs officials will not be able to close it; mission impossible. So bringing back customs posts on the border in Ireland will be unworkable as well as politically unacceptable and also an invitation to smugglers to set up shop on the border. Increased surveillance and security will be a direct threat to the peace process if the controls are located on the border in Ireland. The integrity of the customs union demands that a solution be found which keeps the north of Ireland in the EU and in the customs union and the only way to achieve this, short of Irish unity, is through designated special status within the EU and it is something that the Irish Government and this Parliament must insist on.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen.It is difficult to overestimate the work of customs services and the importance of cooperation between national customs, both in combating illegal trade and in ensuring that legitimate trade runs as smoothly and efficiently as possible.I can therefore only welcome the interest of Parliament's Committee on International Trade on this subject and the report on it.Unfortunately, the content of the post does not convince me that it is worth supporting.I say this as a member of the Group of the Greens and as a former mayor of a border municipality in the European Union.In the report, I lacked measures to combat the unjustified increase in traffic and pollution.Furthermore, I cannot agree with the rapporteur's argument for the transfer of responsibility for customs activities from the national to the European Union level.Thank you.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I think we can all agree here that illicit trade and corruption in trade are problems that must be tackled. The rapporteur is spot on when she says that overly complex customs rules can harm SMEs. So a balance is always necessary. But also, every chain is only as strong as its weakest link – and again the rapporteur is absolutely right to recognise issues with so—called forum shopping, where goods are shipped through the area where it is perceived that customs controls are the most lax. So, of course, there are issues. I also note that a recent report by Transparency International shows that, sadly, corruption is the norm and not the exception in public life, ranking 176 countries across the globe for corruption. We see that in the European Union there are countries like Denmark, Sweden, Finland, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom which all come out in the top ten, but there are other EU countries – and I will not name names for the sake of fairness – which are ranked lower than the one-party communist state of Cuba. So, when we talk about clamping down on illicit trade at EU level, there is immediately an issue. And when we look at the EU accession countries – the countries that the EU wants to absorb – the corruption levels seen there are ones that, frankly, would make Al Capone blush and, indeed in one case, are even worse than Iran. Fundamentally, it is the same old problem. When you try to write the same rules across 28 countries, one size never really fits all, and trying to harmonise too much ends up causing problems.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on presenting a very good report. There has been some criticism of this report, and I do not say these words of praise to the rapporteurs very often, and in this case, I really must and must stand up for her work. I would also like to say that the customs union is a great project, and I think it reflects that very common desire of the European Communities, even in some historical context. I would also like to highlight the work of all the customs offices and thank all the customs officers, because they are doing, in my opinion, a great job. It is this cooperation and coordination of customs offices that is absolutely essential for the functioning of the customs union. Of course, smuggling is a long-standing problem, but it certainly cannot be said that it is unsolved. We have established business rules. These are written and are to be observed, and non-compliance must, of course, be sanctioned. That is the equality of those rules. Usually, it is the case that those who do not follow the rules are fundamentally favored, and we should not allow this unequivocally. Ie. the same rules apply to all. If we are to talk about legal entrances to the European market, then, of course, this must happen at the level of ports and other entrances, and they are to function as the only legal entrances. Of course, the illegal trade has many consequences. Whether it is smuggling, promoting organized crime or even terrorism. These are all negative consequences that we are aware of, and where we need to call for cooperation between the Member States, the individual customs offices, so that these negative consequences are really suppressed and combated.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, combating illicit trade is a necessity. We need to increase fair trade, illicit trade kills SMEs first, kills European industry. The customs union and the implementation of the Union Customs Code introduced in 2016 are likely to be ineffective due to the delay in the adequate financing of information systems. I also believe that the type of sanction, criminal or administrative, needs to be clarified in the event of a breach of customs provisions. Commissioner, the European Union has agreements on cooperation and mutual administrative assistance in customs matters with South Korea, Canada, the USA, India, China, Japan. Exactly these countries are responsible for most of the illegal and counterfeit products and then here you have to act: the Commission has to act on the basis of agreements, you have to defend the internal market. I believe that a more in-depth analysis of the situation of illicit trade is needed, and I believe that you, the Commission, need to come to the responsible committees of the European Parliament and report to see what is happening, how this situation is improving, how we can move forward. from an illicit trade to a fair trade and obviously to set concrete measures for the next period. I also strongly believe that there is a need to defend the geographical indications of agri-food products: this is where human health is also endangered. Also, in textile products, where we have alarming situations, there are situations in which children, women, people have become ill from products treated with inappropriate dyes and chemicals.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I consider the standardization and harmonization of customs controls or criminal sanctions to be a step in the right direction.The customs union requires adequate harmonization at EU level.So far, we have different customs procedures, such as customs clearance, revisions, sanctions or controls, which cause fragmentation and, in addition, additional administrative burdens.It is these differences that allow traders in counterfeit or otherwise undervalued goods to access the internal market.The speakers have already assessed this situation sufficiently.The goods are then transported to the destination along an unusual route, avoiding customs clearance control or complicating enforcement.This is an issue that the Commission should definitely address, and I am glad that the Commissioner has committed himself to enforcing the Customs Code and better enforcement of existing law.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the customs union is a fundamental pillar of the European Union. However, some flaws in the current system show criticalities linked to alterations in commercial value, counterfeiting, illicit financial flows and money laundering in commercial activities. Procedural differences at customs, in particular with regard to customs clearance, inspections, sanctions and controls, create fragmentation, divergences in tax collection between Member States and market distortions. Member States' customs authorities need to be proactive in sharing data, cooperating with control bodies and, above all, identifying anomalies related to price manipulation. Only closer customs cooperation can reduce the current gaps in customs control systems, ensuring an effective fight against illicit trade, counterfeiting and fraud and, therefore, protecting commercial operators who carry out their business legally, which usually they are the only ones to pay the consequences of a fragmented customs system.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the customs union is indeed a key pillar of the European operation itself. This means a partnership between the Commission and the Member States. It definitely means a need to simplify customs procedures and activate and facilitate e-commerce. But what we are seeing is that some Member States are turning a blind eye to what is happening and have a different approach to controls. There is also an area from which we really have a violation of customs legislation. We have tax evasion like this, we have smuggling at the same time, all this is intensified by the various free zones that exist. An important problem is the stolen products, ie the "monkey" products, which really disintegrate the European economy. That is why cooperation is needed, interventions are needed to crack down on smuggling itself.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - I thank the chairwoman, congratulate the reporters and greet Vice President Dombrovskis. If we want a customs system that works well and efficiently at the entire external border, it is necessary to break the various practices of the Member States, as colleagues have said, and the exchange of knowledge and experience between the customs administrations of the Member States is crucial. the role of coordinator and additional clarifications to ensure uniform application of the rules. I am glad that Vice President Dombrovskis has confirmed that this is being worked on. Information on illicit trade and unfair companies should be shared, but not only among customs administrations but also among ministries of the interior and other institutions in order to combat fraud at all levels and as effectively as possible. In particular, I would like to emphasize the role of OLAF, which needs to be more active in coordinating related investigations, because speed and synergy are important here, which we only achieve through joint and well-coordinated action. Thank you.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the honourable Members for their comments and for the importance they attach to the external aspects of  customs performance and management as a tool to facilitate trade and fight illicit trade.
