I believe that our two institutions share the same objectives of wishing to have a strong customs policy, which is to first facilitate and accelerate legitimate trade and at the same time have efficient controls on the ground which ensure the safety and security of citizens, making sure of stopping fake or dangerous goods, drugs, explosives and arms from entering the EU market. I would like to underline that the Commission recognises the importance of the external dimension of customs policy. In the recently published reflection paper on harnessing globalisation, further investment in EU customs risk management is seen as one of the means of responding to the challenges of globalisation and ensuring a level playing field. I would like to address some of the points made during the debate. It is true that further work is needed, particularly with regard to strengthening cooperation at all levels, with economic operators, with Member States, with trading partners and also internally with other EU agencies and Commission services. But I can assure you this remains top on our agenda. The Commission will also endeavour to cooperate with other law enforcement administrations in order to achieve a harmonised and integrated control approach. This is the only way to both ensure the safety and security of citizens and to protect the financial interests of the EU. We should also remember that customs intelligence is also invaluable to law enforcement authorities and security agencies and should be fully explored. Finally, I would like to confirm the Commission’s commitment to continue to cooperate closely with the Parliament so as to ensure that EU customs policies indeed are effective, proportionate and fit for purpose.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my thanks again to all colleagues who have actively collaborated on this resolution. I am slightly surprised at some positions, especially my colleague from the Greens, who spoke of harmonization as a problem for the states that are already the most virtuous today. Here, I believe that harmonizing customs controls is, on the other hand, an opportunity especially for those States that are more virtuous today and among these, I also recall Italy, which has a primacy in terms of the severity of controls. Another thing that I would like to point out again to Commissioner Dombrovskis and which has not been mentioned is that we do not need to have only more efficient checks, which certainly will have to be done, but above all it must be recognized that we need uniform checks. This does not depend solely and exclusively on problems linked, as I explained at the beginning of my speech, to illegality, therefore to corruption, but there are also different practices linked to different sensitivities. As I said, during the missions I carried out in the area, I was able to see how there are different technical sensitivities, for which the operators carry out the shopping forum linked to the fact that in certain ports some counterfeit goods would never enter, as the operators are more sensitive about certain topics, and can do it elsewhere. We need to make customs clearance practices more streamlined, faster for operators, but we also need to make sure that it is not possible to bring in goods from a different port simply because there is not the necessary knowledge. some things. I believe this is due above all to all European citizens who thus have the possibility of being defended and protected, but also to economic operators who do not see traffic quotas being subtracted.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - Mr President, This text is in addition to the very many proposals that the European Parliament has long been making to improve cooperation between Member States and the vigilance of all actors in customs matters. Fighting unfair competition is a priority and our customs services, which are doing a remarkable job, must have the means to achieve this ambition. Without endangering new forms of commerce, such as e-commerce, or international trade, the European Union must bring coherence even within its internal market if it wants to continue to develop coherence in international trade. through the WTO or trade agreements. The fight against fraud is one of these objectives, as is the reduction of administrative errors which may occur due to the complexity of certain procedures. All these parameters must be taken into account and I hope that the European Commission and, above all, the Member States will take these proposals into account to better coordinate the difficult but oh so essential work of our customs services.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the report by Sabine Verheyen on the European e-government action plan 2016-2020 (2016/2273 (INI)) (A8-0178 / 2017).

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner! First of all, I would like to thank you for the good and extremely constructive cooperation with the shadow rapporteurs and everyone who has contributed to the report. As rapporteur, I very much welcome the Commission's new eGovernment action plan for the years 2016 to 2020. With our vote tomorrow, we as Parliament are sending out an important signal that we want to support and promote the digitization of public administration and public institutions. With this report we are calling on the Member States to make the public sector fit for the future. Our aim must be to modernize administrative processes and to remove bureaucratic hurdles at all levels. In the age of digitization, the internet has become a part of our everyday life that we can no longer imagine life without. The further development of electronic services and the provision of public online services are therefore imperative in order to improve and make services more efficient for citizens, but also for companies, especially small and medium-sized companies. Digitization makes it possible to make new forms of public services more easily accessible and to guarantee accessibility. A central access portal through which citizens and companies can also have cross-border access to all information and administrative services is a very important step. Another element is the once-only principle, in which citizens and also companies enter their data once and do not have to repeat the same information over and over again. In this way, dealing with authorities can be significantly simplified, and cooperation between different bodies can also be significantly facilitated. Further progress also needs to be made in the area of ​​electronic public procurement Member States are made. This way, bureaucracy can be reduced and more transparency and efficiency can be achieved in the allocation process. Among other things, the implementation and further development of electronic signature systems and the development of standards to enable the interoperability and portability of data sets are important here. To this end, the public authorities must cooperate more closely at all levels. This can lead to a significant increase in the efficiency of public services. In spite of all efforts to push ahead with the digitization of public administrations, we must not forget that still not all Europeans have the same access to the Internet or the necessary digital skills or the necessary trust in digital offerings to use the online services of the public administration also to take advantage of. That is why broadband expansion is a basic requirement for the targeted progress in the eGovernment action plan, particularly in rural regions. We have to give citizens and companies adequate access to the internet so that they can participate in the new forms of electronic administration. In addition, digital skills must be promoted through training and further education opportunities. These competencies have to be developed especially among employees of public bodies, as they are often not so-called digital natives. As long as there is a need for personal support when dealing with authorities and administrative tasks, these services should also be guaranteed in addition to the online offers so that something like this is still possible in the online and offline approach, because we are allowed to use them Don't leave a citizen behind. Citizens should therefore also be offered improved opportunities for further training that also impart digital skills accordingly. An essential point, however, is that especially when handling sensitive and personal data, data protection is generally guaranteed.In this way you can strengthen trust in online services and encourage more people to contact their offices via this route.The eGovernment action plan is an important step towards leveraging the potential of digitization in public administrations and services, improving cooperation and efficiency, and thus making services more transparent and better for citizens and companies, and reducing bureaucratic hurdles.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to start by saying that I welcome the new action plan and that online public services are a priority for the 21st century.The digitization of public administration and the digitization of public administration procedures is absolutely key to our future.I also welcome the demand that, by 2022, all public administrations be open and transparent.It is a relatively ambitious goal.I would also like to welcome the demand for the digitization of health services, because these health services can improve the quality of life of citizens.Cross-border eGovernment is crucial for the realization of all 4 freedoms that underpin the EU.In general, I would like to welcome this action plan.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, we are now seeing a giant, international cyber attack wreak havoc on private and public computer systems across the world, including the National Health Service in the UK. This is a wake—up call on the need to invest in our e-government systems and cyber security. In the meantime, there is a real risk to our very democracy that comes from harvesting and analysing online data. New technologies enable secretive, private companies to target social media users and determine what information they see. The Guardian journalist Carole Cadwalladr has exposed worrying links between the far right, the Brexit Leave campaigns, Donald Trump, the Russian Government and technology companies owned by the Conservative billionaire Robert Mercer. It appears that the funding of electoral campaigns is opaque and under the radar, provoking legal questions. As we seek to protect our governments and democracies, we must take action to adapt our laws in order to prevent such unethical manipulation of voters online, and instead use online platforms for open and transparent democratic debate.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, e-government is very important, because that is how we will deal effectively with bureaucracy. Transactions will be facilitated, the administrative burden will be reduced during the production process itself. It also means strengthening cross-border e-government. Of course, we need to see how data protection and security issues work. At the same time, it is important to have the exchange of legal information, the interconnection of the public with the private sector. It is important to have access to electronic services, in a phase in which we all live, it is impossible to imagine the very operation of the economy, but also of the administration itself, without the use of the Internet. It is therefore crucial that we move effectively to e-government.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, the proximity of the various services of the State to all sections of the population has, in the so-called e-government, a useful tool to be exploited more fully. But precisely in the name of this proximity and elementary criteria of equality and universality, this should not be an excuse to further divest in public services. It is necessary to take into account the limitations of access to the network and new technologies by some sections of the population. It is one thing to place technological advances at the service of populations, making life easier for them, another, quite distinct and even the opposite, to use the digitization of the State as a pretext to suppress forms of physical and direct contact with State services whenever they are necessary, making people's lives more difficult. In addition, it would be important to end the enormous dependence of States on software produced by multinationals, which hurts them financially and not only blocks innovation but leaves colossal volumes of data at the mercy of the economic and political interests of these multinationals and governments of others. countries.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - I would also look at the latest cyber-attack, the hacker attack, which showed how frightening these attacks are, which will, of course, be more and more frequent.On an annual level, there is about € 100 billion in damage from various cyber attacks, and even when we talk about the eGovernment Action Plan, I think we need to pay a lot, a lot of attention to security as well.Especially the state administration, of course this public sector is increasingly using the so-called e-commerce, digitalization ... of course, this set of different data also means a nice invitation to hackers to blackmail, not only individuals, not only companies, butin some cases also individual countries.And that is why - once again - I think that the European Commission must also give special importance to this area of cyber security, in order to prevent abuses and, of course, to ensure security.However, this electronic system must be user-friendly.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - I thank the chairman.A modern state administration at the service of citizens and entrepreneurs, an administration that responds quickly to inquiries, issues permits and solutions quickly, is crucial for the development of the economy and society.Without digitalization and the introduction of e-business, it is difficult to achieve acceleration.Digitization usually encourages the regulation of processes and procedures, simplification, elimination of overlaps and thus significantly affects the acceleration of the work of the administration.Digitization is important for improving transparency, opening the state to citizens, facilitating communication and thus helping to develop cooperation, partnership and joint work with citizens.It is transparency, openness and partnership that strengthen trust, and trust is once again the foundation of growth and development.That is why I support this action plan, which is an important message to all of us to work on transparency, simplification, acceleration and confidence-building.Thank you.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I want to tell you that I support the report and I congratulate the rapporteur and all those who have contributed. As the rapporteur has said, the development of e-government is a key element of the digital single market, but it is important to develop secure, reliable cross-border services in order to avoid market fragmentation. But, unfortunately, there is a major difference between rural and urban areas in terms of internet connection. In 2015, only 28% of European households in rural areas benefit from the connection. I welcome the introduction of e-Codex, which allows direct communication between citizens and courts in all Member States, but what do we do with citizens who do not have these connections? I believe that with the development of e-government there is a need to increase security and defense against cyber attacks. I believe that there is a need to improve citizens' skills in the digital field, otherwise investment in e-government will not achieve its goal and I am sure that, in conclusion, Commissioner, I believe that the number one priority is to have connections in both rural and urban areas.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Thank you, Madam Chair.Digital innovation and the wider adoption of new information technologies represent a great opportunity for public administration to finally become what citizens want it to be - accessible, fast, efficient and minimally visible.The rapporteur is well aware of key challenges such as infrastructure development and broadband internet connection, as well as the need to educate users and administrative staff.But what I think is the greatest value of this report is the promotion of a dual approach because we really must not in any way exclude citizens who, for various objective reasons, do not use digital services and tools.The dual approach may not provide as drastic savings as full digitization, but I believe that there is enough room for it to reduce public administration to some realistic framework within national, regional and local budgets.Thank you very much.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - The need to build and develop e-government services is now closely linked to the functioning of democracies. Citizens see it as a service to perform public tasks in return for the taxes they pay. The Union institutions must support this approach to service providers, which has not yet become established in all Member States. The widespread use of e-services is also a natural consequence of this service provider approach. In line with the rapporteur, we must also draw attention to the fact that the modernization of public services is not limited to developments in information technology. An efficient and citizen-friendly administrative staff that personally addresses the needs of the population remains key. Such an efficient administration can also strengthen citizens' confidence in democracy and the state's ability to act, so it is in the interest of each state to devote special resources to the development of this area.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the digitization of public services contributes to citizens' understanding of public services by intensifying dialogue with public authorities, increasing transparency and improving the cost-effectiveness of services. The new action plan for eGovernment 2016-2020 presented by the European Commission sets ambitious goals, assuming an open, efficient and inclusive digitalized administration, with end-to-end digital public services without borders, personalized and intuitive for citizens and for all businesses. I am pleased to note the particular attention paid to the aspect of personal data protection, which is essential for obtaining the trust of citizens and guaranteeing the success of the strategy adopted. Instead, I notice little attention to the issue of safety. For several days, dozens of European states and have not been in check of hackers who have threatened the destruction of billions and billions of data. Just a few hours ago, we learn that the virus used seems to have been eradicated. Cybersecurity is fundamental and perhaps more investments need to be encouraged and made in this area.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I also want to support this report. Commissioner, when I worked in the Czech Republic, I was responsible for eGovernment in the Czech Republic and my experience is that the projects are very important, they are very costly, very laborious, implementation usually takes over one term and so I have the last feel that national politicians are reluctant to invest time in the development of eGovernment. That is why I think it is very important that the European Commission deals with this issue at a central level, and it is at least up to you, Commissioner, to press individual, say national policies, individual national governments not to underestimate the issue of eGovernment, , which voters cannot immediately appreciate, which does not bring immediate political points, so this is an extremely important topic, as my colleagues have made clear during their speeches. The European Commission, the European Parliament, need to support this in order to explain to national politicians why eGovernment needs to be implemented.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Madam President, the report on the European eGovernment Action Plan 2016-2020 reiterates the need for public administrations to switch to digital technology, to work more closely with each other at European level, but also to introduce mechanisms to enable better interconnection of data. The benefits are important: from lowering costs to a significant saving of time and resources for citizens. But I can't talk about the benefits of digitization today without referring to the Wannacry cyber attack. Europol estimates that there are a total of more than two hundred thousand victims in almost the whole world. Many institutions in Europe have been affected, sometimes we are talking about patients who could not access their data, many European companies were blocked, for example, in Romania, Dacia plants had to stop operating. Interestingly, a young man in his early twenties accidentally blocked the attack, which shows that European administrations need to work more closely, mechanisms to combat cybercrime on the Internet need to be strengthened, the agency responsible for cybersecurity needs to be reformed, and protection data must become a priority topic for everyone.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Verheyen, and the shadow rapporteurs for a very good parliamentary report on the eGovernment Action Plan. There is more to eGovernment than just putting up websites and offering public services online. Its impact is much more far—reaching. It is a key enabler in achieving the transformation of Europe’s public administration, contributing to growth, competitiveness and quality of life. One major achievement of the first year is the proposed draft regulation on the single digital gateway, which also introduced the once—only principle at European level. With the addition of five new actions to the Action Plan, the mid-term review of the digital single market confirms this. The challenge is not to introduce digital technologies into public administrations, but rather the integration of digital technologies into public sector modernisation efforts. It is its transformative nature, impacting all levels of government and various public policy domains, that has great potential to bring significant benefits. The smart use of ICT by governments can help deliver better policies and decisions to tackle the pressing social and economic challenges of our times. By becoming more open and transparent, government and public bodies become more accountable and trustworthy. This report provides an additional layer to the topic of eGovernment in general. Indeed, it provides further food for thought in terms of developing future actions to be included in the Action Plan in the coming years. I am encouraged that all EU institutions share a common vision on what the future of eGovernment will look like. This vision can only be reached if all stakeholders embrace it and commit themselves to working together to make it a reality: governments, public bodies at all levels – European, national, regional and local – and also industry, business and citizens. The European Parliament is uniquely placed in this mission. On the one hand, it can communicate to its constituents the benefits of this digital transformation. On the other hand, it can work together with the Commission in adopting eGovernment—related legislative proposals. One of the key themes of the eGovernment Action Plan is that the Commission shall lead by example in applying the underlying principles of the Action Plan, such as digital by default, cross—border by default, and applying the once-only principle. The Commission is taking its commitment seriously and also offers Member States, local and regional administrations and other stakeholders financial support to accelerate the digital transformation of government. This is being done through various programmes, including structural funds, the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020, and I am confident that Parliament will also wish to lead by example and it can count on the full support of the Commission in advancing the digital transformation of government.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. - The modernization of the internal market is one of the fundamental commitments of this European legislature, which is proceeding in several sectors and which certainly needs a strong impetus from the national public institutions themselves. This is an objective to be achieved, first of all, through a complete digitalization of our internal administrations, which must thus be made more open and closer to citizens and businesses and able to respond to the challenges of competitiveness and new forms of production. E-Government is not only an internal operational tool for public administration: it also represents a flywheel for economic development capable of reducing costs and procedures, opening new financing, planning and investment channels. Among the key points for the development of E-Government, the introduction of new and simpler methods of action for businesses should therefore be strongly encouraged, in particular through a thorough review of the rules on the digital dimension of company law. This is a topic that will be very topical in the short term, by virtue of the progress that Parliament is making in the dossier of the reform of cross-border mergers and divisions.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - Digital change of public administrations is a key element in realizing the full potential of the single market. Digital public services reduce the administrative burden for citizens and businesses, thus speeding up and simplifying interaction with public administrations, which are becoming more transparent and cheaper. In this context, I believe that it is necessary to ensure the transition to digital administration at national and European level, but also at local and regional level, to enable accessibility and universal accessibility, and to make additional efforts to promote digital solutions. We need to adapt the modernization of public administration to a changing environment in order to achieve economic and social benefits for society as a whole. Furthermore, it is important to provide high-speed internet access to all European households, especially those in rural areas that are lagging behind with the development of high-speed broadband internet connection. The success of the EU eGovernment Action Plan, which I support, should take into account data protection and security in order to guarantee privacy and increase confidence in information and communication technologies.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – Connectivity, innovation, trust and skills are the basic principles for enhancing the full potential of eGovernance in Europe. As the report puts it – digital first. I would add European-in-design – interconnectivity, interoperability, cross—border by nature – key to a true European eGovernance. The EU has to make sure that the furthest villages and islands are connected to high-speed internet, developing 5G networks to be available to everyone as soon as possible. Being connected should be a right, not a privilege! Investing in resilient, trustworthy and sustainable e-solutions may seem costly at first, yet the long-term benefits in administrative, financial and communication terms will prove to be worth the initial costs. Equally, investments are needed to dramatically increase the level of digital literacy and cyber hygiene. Citizens need reassurances, full transparency and accountability on how their data is treated to make full use of e-solutions. Lastly, mobile solutions need to be included from the beginning in any development of eGovernance. In 2016, 59% of EU citizens connected themselves to internet via mobile devices; these numbers keep growing. Mobile by design is the mainstream future.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute interventions on important political issues (Rule 163).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - In this one minute, I would like to draw attention to a problem that is not much talked about here.It is a problem with turning tachometers or fraud on so-called odometers.It is a relatively simple manipulation.You can earn EUR 1 000 in about a minute, Commissioner.Who wouldn't want that?In Poland, in Germany, in other countries, this problem is constantly rampant and growing.Despite constant alerts, the Commission is not responding to this problem.Commissioner, a third of used cars have rolled kilometers.This is not only a problem in the Czech Republic, but it is also a problem in Germany.I am therefore asking you whether the Commission will finally stop pushing its head in the sand and really start addressing these issues, which really bother EU citizens, and whether it will really do anything about them.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, this past winter I denounced to the European Commission the abusive prices of the Spanish electricity sector and, especially, how during the cold wave they had broken records in Spain. This is causing enormous social alarm in my country, derived from the importance of the price of energy in the shopping basket and the serious problems of energy poverty, which have caused fatal accidents in recent months. Well, Commissioner Vestager, very kindly, told me that she would follow the case very closely. This last week we have learned that an anti-corruption prosecutor has formally accused Iberdrola, a large Spanish electricity company, for manipulating prices in the winter of the cold wave, in 2013. So I would ask the Competition department to take action on the matter, to investigate the Spanish electricity sector and the possible manipulation of its prices in an abusive way for years, especially during winters, when the citizens have more needs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the analgesia of the SYRIZA-ANEL government has now turned red, since the memorandum measures that are being promoted in the Greek Parliament for a vote this week pave the way for a new social Armageddon. Under the orders of the troika, measures for the period 2019-2020 amounting to 4.6 billion euros are placed, which will reach 4.9 billion euros in 2021. Measures that cut the already reduced and meager pensions, as well as the tax-free, paving the way for the tax evasion of the Greek people. At the same time, the famous countermeasures are ashes in the eyes, which will be implemented only with the consent of the troika and on the condition that the Greek people will be outraged and PPC and the country's ports will have been sold out. However, with the strike on Wednesday, the Greek people are preparing to send a strong message of resistance and struggle to the troika and the government, because there is another way.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, first I would like to thank rapporteur Ulrike Lunacek for her Kosovo report, the debate on which has, unfortunately, been postponed. It is true that Kosovo has made some progress but there is still room for improvement, for example to ensure the security of journalists, as we can conclude from the recent attacks on journalist Arbana Xharra. However, Kosovo should not remain the only Western Balkan country that does not enjoy visa-free travel. The citizens of Kosovo, especially young people, deserve the freedom to move freely. The border demarcation with Montenegro should not be used for political fights, new elections or blame games, as it has been used already, because the next opposition can repeat the game and then there is no end to it. The Kosovo Parliament must finalise this question, preferably before the elections, and then it will be up to the EU to keep its promise and grant visa-free travel to the citizens of Kosovo.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL). Madam President, in the last seven years, the Greek people have been subjected to financial sacrifices such that there is no comparable historical example of another European country in peacetime. All this is done with the declared goal of the Greek state regaining its solvency and being able to borrow from the capital markets. However, it must be understood that the primary surpluses in the Greek budget are not enough to achieve the goal, but a lightening of the huge burden of public debt is required. The other eurozone Member States must provide this relief as requested by the International Monetary Fund. It is hypocritical for the lenders to request the participation of the Fund in the program and the implementation of its requirements for austerity measures on the part of the Greek side, but to delay the debt relief that they have repeatedly promised. Give Greece a real opportunity.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Madam President, the Spanish State continues with its judicial persecution against the Catalan democratic institutions, committed to the referendum on self-determination. Last week, the president of the Parliament of Catalonia and other members of the table had to testify before the judge for having allowed, in plenary, a debate and a vote on the path to the referendum, and the next episode of this obsessive persecution It seems that it will be to prohibit the purchase of ballot boxes - the Government of Catalonia has announced that it will buy ballot boxes, which is the instrument that Democrats use to decide. Well, Mr. Rajoy, who must think that this thing about the polls is something very subversive, has already put the Prosecutor's Office to work to prevent it. It is serious that the president of a Parliament has to explain before a judge why she does not prevent a debate and a vote in Parliament; it is serious that buying ballot boxes is a crime; It is serious that, in the name of the law, democracy and its institutions are restricted. It is serious that all this is happening here in Europe. It is very serious, but they will not stop us because they will not stop democracy.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, the fourth memorandum, the second of the SYRIZA-ANEL government, which is currently being passed by the Greek Parliament, is the departure of capital for profit and the ticket of the people to a worse slaughterhouse. Slaughter of pensions, wages, unemployment benefits, heating, disability, tax evasion and the poorest, mass layoffs, abolition of Sunday holidays, collective bargaining, the right to strike, employer lock-out, privatization of everything. Funded by the rest of the poor for extreme poverty, if the measures - slaughterhouse succeed, are crumbs in front of the countermeasures in favor of capital with new tax exemptions and subsidies. The New Democracy and the rest of the bourgeois opposition, demagogically, do not vote for the measures, but swear to implement them. The capital, more and more gained, the people, more and more lost. That is why he should not choose a butcher, but put an end to the slaughter himself. The strike on May 17 to become the beginning of an escalating popular counterattack lasting the eradication of evil: that fewer and fewer are stealing the sweat of more and more, with the help of bourgeois governments and the European Union.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to talk about the issue of spending European funds, because the issue of EU policy coherence and growth in the regions is, in my view, a fundamental and genuine priority.Balancing the gap between lagging regions is one of the strengths on which the EU is undoubtedly built.It is necessary to address the increase in bureaucracy that is driven from the European level in the use of these European funds.This is truly unprecedented and unusual.We have reached three times the rules for drawing European funds than in previous periods.We must also realize that the Commission is undoubtedly also to blame, because it fundamentally erred in its laxity when approving operational programs.I want to call on the Commission and the EU institutions to help the Member States absorb European funds by approving and easing the administrative burden.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: - Madam President, I wanted to draw your attention to a request from the United Nations special agency for equality: the UN Women agency. On the calendar of our institutions, even today, events and official announcements around March 8 are entitled "International Women's Day", or even "Women's Day". This vagueness encourages the silliest interpretations that we see flourish with each new "Women's Day." However, should it be remembered that this day is not a celebration of absolute and eternal femininity, and even less the opportunity for large-scale distribution to destock household appliances or cosmetics? On the contrary, this date should make it possible to combat the very real obstacles to women's autonomy and security. It is a time of awareness and mobilization essential for our commitments against discrimination. And we know that language is a key issue in the fight for gender equality. This is why we need to be specific and talk about "International Women's Rights Day" just as we celebrate "Human Rights Day". This is why I adopted this request from the UN Women agency and demand that we clarify the terms of the calendars of our institutions.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, 29 days have passed since 1,500 Palestinians detained in Israeli prisons started a hunger strike in protest against Israel's denial of basic rights enshrined in international law and in various conventions. For access to medical assistance, for the non-subjection of prisoners to torture and other forms of violent, cruel, degrading and inhuman treatment, for the knowledge of the charges and their formalization, for the possibility of accessing the respective processes, meeting with the defense and receiving visits from relatives. In view of the scale of the protest and its duration, in view of the serious state of health in which these prisoners are, it is shocking the inhumanity of the Israeli authorities, who refuse to transfer them to hospital units, keeping them in isolation. But it is just as shocking the silence, inaction and complicit indifference of the European Union and its institutions, which are always so quick to wave the flag of human rights on other occasions. Here, we want to express our solidarity with the Palestinian political prisoners and demand their immediate release, at the same time that we denounce this hypocrisy.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Madam President, today I will refer again - I did it in 2014 - to the scam, the danger and the offense that the failed project of the Castor gas warehouse, located in Spain, which directly affects the area of ​​Vinaròs and the Ebro delta. At the time, the budget tripled incomprehensibly. After dozens of earthquakes, Mr. Florentino Pérez received 3.15 billion euros, because he had contractually shielded his failure. Now, maintaining useless and dangerous installations costs us more than fifteen million euros each year, which is charged, like all expenses, to the receipt of electricity from the Spanish for the next more than thirty years. This is a huge nonsense, a fraudulent and criminal nonsense. We will not tire of reporting it. Is the European Commission ready to do something in favor of Spanish citizens? Because I do not believe that fraud and aggression to the environment are part of the European project.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I want to acquaint you with one serious case, which happened on May 6-7, 2017, when a 59-year-old Czech veterinarian was detained on the A3 motorway near Nuremberg, carrying 42 puppies in the trunk of a car, which was in poor condition.It was intended for sale in Belgium.Ladies and gentlemen, this particular case of 42 puppies, some of which have unfortunately already died, clearly shows the extremely serious form of crime that is taking place in Europe today, namely the smuggling of animals from the eastern EU to the western part of the EU.It is a form of serious crime that generates extraordinary money.Unfortunately, a large number of animals will succumb and die, and we should fight against that.I call on the Commission, Commissioner, to finally take this form of serious action into account and to force the EU countries to cooperate and combat animal smuggling.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Colleagues, dear compatriots, for more than 13 months the European Commission has been trampling on its own legislation, not protecting 70 million citizens of the Union from discrimination. Only a few days ago, she confirmed that she would not change her position on the introduction of a visa for American citizens, despite her obligation to do so. This confirmed the thesis that it prefers to violate European legislation instead of introducing a visa for third countries that discriminate against Europeans, including us Bulgarians. From this podium, I call on the Bulgarian government, represented by the Prime Minister and the Minister of Foreign Affairs, to take legal action against the European Commission in this case. Bulgarians deserve to be treated as full-fledged Europeans after 10 years of membership in the European Union. Prove that the national interest and the Bulgarians are a priority, not the dictation of any other external geopolitical factor!

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Madam President, Ládio Veron, leader of the Guaraní Kaiowá people, will visit the European Parliament at the end of May. It will do so six months after this House passes an urgent Resolution addressed to the High Representative for Foreign Affairs, the Brazilian authorities and the United Nations. Six months in which no progress has been made and in which the situation of this town has worsened. In March, army helicopters flew over villages of the Guarani Kaiowás, from which armed men came down to intimidate and threaten the population, a practice they are used to. Also multinationals, such as Shell, continue to pollute the aquifer of their territories with monocultures for biofuels, another issue for which this Parliament has already called for greater control and protection of human rights. The universal right to life, land and water should lead us to do more from the European Union: demand more reliably the demarcation of ancestral lands and sanction those multinationals that murder this people. Let's not receive Ládio empty-handed, but with commitments.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Madam President, symbolic gestures are as important in politics as practical solutions.They express value orientation and basic priorities.When the UN General Assembly declared May 15 as International Family Day in 1994, it was a signal that people around the world understood the importance of the family for the functioning of society.A similar gesture has been lacking for years on the part of the European Commission, but also of the governments of the member states, including Slovakia.Finding the courage to join the family is the first step in bringing a family perspective into laws and policies.This year's Family Day theme is the role of families in supporting the education and well-being of their members.We will use it as an opportunity to at least symbolically appreciate the work of all care providers in families.Mom, father, grandparent or sibling.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent elections in some Member States show that populism can be defeated, at least in continental Europe. They prove that the illusions of false nationalist solutions have been firmly rejected by the citizens. Europeans are certainly much more mature than some commentators suggest. But I believe that the European Union needs victory in all the Member States and not just in a few. In some states, victories are up to the election, while in others, a victory for the Union would mean, for example, that those countries would be treated much better and more fairly in the construction of Europe. Romania, dear colleagues, a truly pro-European country, deserves to be included in the Schengen area for years. Romania deserves to get rid of the shameful stigma of MCV. For our Union to have a solid future, all the member states that, like Romania, support a more integrated, stronger and closer to the citizens must be equal. Happy birthday, Europe!

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: - Madam President, in the name of our own resolutions, in the name of international law, in the name of the Geneva Convention, of which the European Union recognizes the application, we cannot be silent on the hunger strike that had to cut into the Palestinian political prisoners. The strike, which began on April 17, aims to obtain detention conditions in accordance with humanitarian law and to put an end to arbitrary administrative detentions. Continuing to ignore these humanitarian demands can lead to even more tensions among the Palestinian population which can themselves lead to the worst. So we have a responsibility to act. I propose that our Parliament set up a commission of inquiry into the situation of Palestinian prisoners. On the other hand, our silence in the face of imprisonment and colonization makes us complicit in the violation of international law. The European Union, however, has an effective leverage with the suspension of the association agreement with Israel. We are now proposing to take action.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner. First of all, I welcome the positive decision of the European Council on the visa waiver for Ukraine. The visa waiver is a positive gesture on the part of the EU and will hopefully inspire Ukraine to implement effective reforms. Ukraine borders seven countries, and its gateway to the EU is the westernmost county, Transcarpathia, which borders four EU member states. Much of the traffic to the EU passes through here, but border crossings are already congested, their infrastructure is outdated and there are few of them. Thus, despite the visa waiver, it will not be easy for citizens to get to the European Union. In addition to visa-free travel, it is therefore essential to develop border infrastructure and areas, to open new border crossings, to modernize the railway and road system, and to include it in international traffic. It is important to end the hours of waiting at border crossings. Citizens with valid travel documents must have dignified travel conditions when entering the European Union. Mobility is a fundamental principle of the European Union, and the EU must also provide effective technical and financial assistance to facilitate this.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like you to listen to me too. Today is International Family Day and I want to raise a desperate case: a Romanian citizen, Mrs. Camelia Smicală, settled for twelve years in Finland, all her rights, human rights, children's rights have been violated. Two minors were brutally picked up from the house and taken (and the children separated) to foster homes, the lady not being notified of a court ruling obtained by her Finnish husband. Moreover, on April 28, she is sentenced to six months in prison for defaming the authorities who took the children two years ago. What are we, the Parliament, the Commission doing to really defend the family? Placing the child in state custody must be the last option when we want to protect children. Do we want to protect the mother's children? I am a mother and I do not think that any mother who is healthy and can take care of her children should ever be separated from her children. I call on the Commission to investigate this case and to ask the Finnish authorities to leave the children with the mother.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - A few months ago, in the autumn of 2016, I talked here about the fact that the fight against corruption in Romania, in addition to its obvious positives, involves serious excesses. At that time, I said that the accusation of corruption in Târgu Mureş was being used to completely make a Hungarian-language school in Romania impossible. I can repeat this today because the situation has not been resolved since then, in fact, parents are being interrogated by anti-corruption prosecutors in turn and trying to intimidate and destabilize them. The purpose of the authorities is clear: to question the functioning and future of the school. Exactly how this can be deduced from the noble goals of the fight against corruption, and possibly other reasons, I leave it to you to judge. What is certain, however, is the need to address the problems of national minorities at European level, as detailed in the Minority SafePack European Citizens' Initiative registered by the Commission. That is why I ask you, like the President of the European Parliament, to support this initiative in the coming period, because its success will also be the success of European citizens.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: - Madam President, dear colleagues, in 1921 the Ioan Cantacuzino Institute of Serums and Vaccines was established in Bucharest, a scientific center that played an important role in the health of Romanians and not only theirs. At EU level, the Cantacuzino Institute is part of the strategic network on which Europe's prompt response to a widespread epidemic depends. Basically, these institutes are the main response unit in a generalized epidemic, but they are totally neglected in the management of the European Union, and their staffing, training and operation are left to the Member States. In other words, in the event of a continental biological crisis, we expect a widespread response from a nationally administered institution, a response that will certainly not be the one we want. I am campaigning for a legislative project to fund the Cantacuzino Institute and similar European institutes from national budgets to the European Union budget, with the aim of providing a functioning system through which Europe can respond effectively, in real time, to one of the the darkest scenarios, whether it's a pandemic or a biological attack. Please join me in this endeavor.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have a lot of friends in France and I was very worried about the rise of populism in France.France is a founding country of the European Union and plays a key role in its development.I also recall the richness of relations between France and my country - the Czech Republic - and, for these reasons, I was delighted with the result of the presidential election.Emmanuel Macron, as president, represents the hope of a policy of European construction respectful of other countries.After Brexit, we need to restore citizens' confidence in the European institutions.Emmanuel Macron faces difficult tasks: to unite France and unite Europe.It raised great expectations.I wish him success, for the success of a united Europe.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - The Schengen area was set up in order to allow citizens of the Member States of the Union free movement between countries.The task of the border Member States of the Schengen area is to ensure good protection of the external borders.Otherwise, “Schengen” loses its meaning.However, due to the tightened controls resulting from the implementation of the Schengen border control regulation, waiting times at borders are being extended in some places.In Slovenia, a lot of dust has been raised by stricter controls on the border with Croatia, which - I think so - are mainly the fault of the governments of both countries, which have not properly prepared for the implementation of the regulation.Stricter controls on the border with Slovenia have also been introduced by Austria and Italy, and all this shows that countries do not trust control and security in the European Union.And we will have to decide together whether we will carefully guard the Schengen border from the outside, or whether the internal borders will become a reality again.I hope, of course, that we decide on the first option.

text: This agenda item is closed.
